SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: _[SCENE.—A room furnished comfortably and tastefully, but not

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: extravagantly. At the back, a door to the right leads to the

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: entrance-hall, another to the left leads to Helmer’s study. Between the

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: doors stands a piano. In the middle of the left-hand wall is a door,

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: and beyond it a window. Near the window are a round table, arm-chairs

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: and a small sofa. In the right-hand wall, at the farther end, another

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: door; and on the same side, nearer the footlights, a stove, two easy

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: chairs and a rocking-chair; between the stove and the door, a small

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: table. Engravings on the walls; a cabinet with china and other small

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: objects; a small book-case with well-bound books. The floors are

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: carpeted, and a fire burns in the stove. It is winter._

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: _A bell rings in the hall; shortly afterwards the door is heard to

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: open. Enter NORA, humming a tune and in high spirits. She is in outdoor

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: dress and carries a number of parcels; these she lays on the table to

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: the right. She leaves the outer door open after her, and through it is

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: seen a PORTER who is carrying a Christmas Tree and a basket, which he

SPEAKER: ACT III
TEXT: gives to the MAID who has opened the door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Hide the Christmas Tree carefully, Helen. Be sure the children do not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: see it until this evening, when it is dressed. _[To the PORTER, taking

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: out her purse.]_ How much?

SPEAKER: PORTER
TEXT: Sixpence.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: There is a shilling. No, keep the change. _[The PORTER thanks her, and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: goes out. NORA shuts the door. She is laughing to herself, as she takes

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: off her hat and coat. She takes a packet of macaroons from her pocket

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and eats one or two; then goes cautiously to her husband’s door and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: listens.]_ Yes, he is in. _[Still humming, she goes to the table on the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: right.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[calls out from his room]_. Is that my little lark twittering out

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: there?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[busy opening some of the parcels]_. Yes, it is!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Is it my little squirrel bustling about?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: When did my squirrel come home?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Just now. _[Puts the bag of macaroons into her pocket and wipes her

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: mouth.]_ Come in here, Torvald, and see what I have bought.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Don’t disturb me. _[A little later, he opens the door and looks into

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: the room, pen in hand.]_ Bought, did you say? All these things? Has my

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: little spendthrift been wasting money again?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes but, Torvald, this year we really can let ourselves go a little.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: This is the first Christmas that we have not needed to economise.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Still, you know, we can’t spend money recklessly.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, Torvald, we may be a wee bit more reckless now, mayn’t we? Just a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tiny wee bit! You are going to have a big salary and earn lots and lots

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of money.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, after the New Year; but then it will be a whole quarter before the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: salary is due.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Pooh! we can borrow until then.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora! _[Goes up to her and takes her playfully by the ear.]_ The same

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: little featherhead! Suppose, now, that I borrowed fifty pounds today,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and you spent it all in the Christmas week, and then on New Year’s Eve

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: a slate fell on my head and killed me, and—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting her hands over his mouth]_. Oh! don’t say such horrid things.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Still, suppose that happened,—what then?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If that were to happen, I don’t suppose I should care whether I owed

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: money or not.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, but what about the people who had lent it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: They? Who would bother about them? I should not know who they were.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That is like a woman! But seriously, Nora, you know what I think about

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: that. No debt, no borrowing. There can be no freedom or beauty about a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: home life that depends on borrowing and debt. We two have kept bravely

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: on the straight road so far, and we will go on the same way for the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: short time longer that there need be any struggle.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[moving towards the stove]_. As you please, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[following her]_. Come, come, my little skylark must not droop her

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: wings. What is this! Is my little squirrel out of temper? _[Taking out

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: his purse.]_ Nora, what do you think I have got here?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[turning round quickly]_. Money!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There you are. _[Gives her some money.]_ Do you think I don’t know what

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: a lot is wanted for housekeeping at Christmas-time?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[counting]_. Ten shillings—a pound—two pounds! Thank you, thank you,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald; that will keep me going for a long time.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Indeed it must.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, yes, it will. But come here and let me show you what I have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: bought. And all so cheap! Look, here is a new suit for Ivar, and a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: sword; and a horse and a trumpet for Bob; and a doll and dolly’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: bedstead for Emmy,—they are very plain, but anyway she will soon break

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: them in pieces. And here are dress-lengths and handkerchiefs for the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: maids; old Anne ought really to have something better.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And what is in this parcel?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[crying out]_. No, no! you mustn’t see that until this evening.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Very well. But now tell me, you extravagant little person, what would

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you like for yourself?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: For myself? Oh, I am sure I don’t want anything.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, but you must. Tell me something reasonable that you would

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: particularly like to have.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I really can’t think of anything—unless, Torvald—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[playing with his coat buttons, and without raising her eyes to his]_.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If you really want to give me something, you might—you might—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well, out with it!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[speaking quickly]_. You might give me money, Torvald. Only just as

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: much as you can afford; and then one of these days I will buy something

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: with it.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But, Nora—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, do! dear Torvald; please, please do! Then I will wrap it up in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: beautiful gilt paper and hang it on the Christmas Tree. Wouldn’t that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: be fun?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What are little people called that are always wasting money?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Spendthrifts—I know. Let us do as you suggest, Torvald, and then I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: shall have time to think what I am most in want of. That is a very

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: sensible plan, isn’t it?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[smiling]_. Indeed it is—that is to say, if you were really to save

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: out of the money I give you, and then really buy something for

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: yourself. But if you spend it all on the housekeeping and any number of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: unnecessary things, then I merely have to pay up again.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh but, Torvald—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You can’t deny it, my dear little Nora. _[Puts his arm round her

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: waist.]_ It’s a sweet little spendthrift, but she uses up a deal of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: money. One would hardly believe how expensive such little persons are!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It’s a shame to say that. I do really save all I can.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[laughing]_. That’s very true,—all you can. But you can’t save

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: anything!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[smiling quietly and happily]_. You haven’t any idea how many expenses

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: we skylarks and squirrels have, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You are an odd little soul. Very like your father. You always find some

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: new way of wheedling money out of me, and, as soon as you have got it,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: it seems to melt in your hands. You never know where it has gone.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Still, one must take you as you are. It is in the blood; for indeed it

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: is true that you can inherit these things, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Ah, I wish I had inherited many of papa’s qualities.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And I would not wish you to be anything but just what you are, my sweet

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: little skylark. But, do you know, it strikes me that you are looking

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: rather—what shall I say—rather uneasy today?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do I?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You do, really. Look straight at me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looks at him]_. Well?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[wagging his finger at her]_. Hasn’t Miss Sweet Tooth been breaking

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: rules in town today?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No; what makes you think that?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Hasn’t she paid a visit to the confectioner’s?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I assure you, Torvald—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not been nibbling sweets?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, certainly not.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not even taken a bite at a macaroon or two?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, Torvald, I assure you really—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There, there, of course I was only joking.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going to the table on the right]_. I should not think of going

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: against your wishes.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No, I am sure of that; besides, you gave me your word— _[Going up to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: her.]_ Keep your little Christmas secrets to yourself, my darling. They

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: will all be revealed tonight when the Christmas Tree is lit, no doubt.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Did you remember to invite Doctor Rank?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No. But there is no need; as a matter of course he will come to dinner

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: with us. However, I will ask him when he comes in this morning. I have

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: ordered some good wine. Nora, you can’t think how I am looking forward

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: to this evening.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: So am I! And how the children will enjoy themselves, Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It is splendid to feel that one has a perfectly safe appointment, and a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: big enough income. It’s delightful to think of, isn’t it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It’s wonderful!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Do you remember last Christmas? For a full three weeks beforehand you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: shut yourself up every evening until long after midnight, making

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: ornaments for the Christmas Tree, and all the other fine things that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: were to be a surprise to us. It was the dullest three weeks I ever

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: spent!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I didn’t find it dull.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[smiling]_. But there was precious little result, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, you shouldn’t tease me about that again. How could I help the cat’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: going in and tearing everything to pieces?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Of course you couldn’t, poor little girl. You had the best of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: intentions to please us all, and that’s the main thing. But it is a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: good thing that our hard times are over.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, it is really wonderful.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: This time I needn’t sit here and be dull all alone, and you needn’t

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: ruin your dear eyes and your pretty little hands—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[clapping her hands]_. No, Torvald, I needn’t any longer, need I! It’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: wonderfully lovely to hear you say so! _[Taking his arm.]_ Now I will

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tell you how I have been thinking we ought to arrange things, Torvald.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: As soon as Christmas is over—_[A bell rings in the hall.]_ There’s the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: bell. _[She tidies the room a little.]_ There’s some one at the door.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What a nuisance!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: If it is a caller, remember I am not at home.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: _[in the doorway]_. A lady to see you, ma’am,—a stranger.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Ask her to come in.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: _[to HELMER]_. The doctor came at the same time, sir.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Did he go straight into my room?

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Yes, sir.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: _[HELMER goes into his room. The MAID ushers in Mrs Linde, who is in

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: travelling dress, and shuts the door.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[in a dejected and timid voice]_. How do you do, Nora?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[doubtfully]_. How do you do—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You don’t recognise me, I suppose.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I don’t know—yes, to be sure, I seem to—_[Suddenly.]_ Yes!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine! Is it really you?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, it is I.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine! To think of my not recognising you! And yet how could I—_[In

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: a gentle voice.]_ How you have altered, Christine!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, I have indeed. In nine, ten long years—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Is it so long since we met? I suppose it is. The last eight years have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: been a happy time for me, I can tell you. And so now you have come into

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the town, and have taken this long journey in winter—that was plucky of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I arrived by steamer this morning.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: To have some fun at Christmas-time, of course. How delightful! We will

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: have such fun together! But take off your things. You are not cold, I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hope. _[Helps her.]_ Now we will sit down by the stove, and be cosy.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, take this armchair; I will sit here in the rocking-chair. _[Takes

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: her hands.]_ Now you look like your old self again; it was only the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: first moment—You are a little paler, Christine, and perhaps a little

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: thinner.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And much, much older, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Perhaps a little older; very, very little; certainly not much. _[Stops

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: suddenly and speaks seriously.]_ What a thoughtless creature I am,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: chattering away like this. My poor, dear Christine, do forgive me.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: What do you mean, Nora?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[gently]_. Poor Christine, you are a widow.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes; it is three years ago now.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I knew; I saw it in the papers. I assure you, Christine, I meant

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: ever so often to write to you at the time, but I always put it off and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: something always prevented me.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I quite understand, dear.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was very bad of me, Christine. Poor thing, how you must have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: suffered. And he left you nothing?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And no children?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nothing at all, then.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Not even any sorrow or grief to live upon.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looking incredulously at her]_. But, Christine, is that possible?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[smiles sadly and strokes her hair]_. It sometimes happens, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: So you are quite alone. How dreadfully sad that must be. I have three

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: lovely children. You can’t see them just now, for they are out with

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: their nurse. But now you must tell me all about it.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, no; I want to hear about you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, you must begin. I mustn’t be selfish today; today I must only think

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of your affairs. But there is one thing I must tell you. Do you know we

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: have just had a great piece of good luck?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, what is it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Just fancy, my husband has been made manager of the Bank!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Your husband? What good luck!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, tremendous! A barrister’s profession is such an uncertain thing,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: especially if he won’t undertake unsavoury cases; and naturally Torvald

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: has never been willing to do that, and I quite agree with him. You may

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: imagine how pleased we are! He is to take up his work in the Bank at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the New Year, and then he will have a big salary and lots of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: commissions. For the future we can live quite differently—we can do

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: just as we like. I feel so relieved and so happy, Christine! It will be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: splendid to have heaps of money and not need to have any anxiety, won’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, anyhow I think it would be delightful to have what one needs.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, not only what one needs, but heaps and heaps of money.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[smiling]_. Nora, Nora, haven’t you learned sense yet? In our

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: schooldays you were a great spendthrift.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[laughing]_. Yes, that is what Torvald says now. _[Wags her finger at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: her.]_ But “Nora, Nora” is not so silly as you think. We have not been

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: in a position for me to waste money. We have both had to work.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You too?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes; odds and ends, needlework, crotchet-work, embroidery, and that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: kind of thing. _[Dropping her voice.]_ And other things as well. You

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: know Torvald left his office when we were married? There was no

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: prospect of promotion there, and he had to try and earn more than

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: before. But during the first year he over-worked himself dreadfully.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You see, he had to make money every way he could, and he worked early

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and late; but he couldn’t stand it, and fell dreadfully ill, and the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: doctors said it was necessary for him to go south.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You spent a whole year in Italy, didn’t you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes. It was no easy matter to get away, I can tell you. It was just

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: after Ivar was born; but naturally we had to go. It was a wonderfully

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: beautiful journey, and it saved Torvald’s life. But it cost a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tremendous lot of money, Christine.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: So I should think.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It cost about two hundred and fifty pounds. That’s a lot, isn’t it?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, and in emergencies like that it is lucky to have the money.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I ought to tell you that we had it from papa.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Oh, I see. It was just about that time that he died, wasn’t it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes; and, just think of it, I couldn’t go and nurse him. I was

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: expecting little Ivar’s birth every day and I had my poor sick Torvald

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: to look after. My dear, kind father—I never saw him again, Christine.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That was the saddest time I have known since our marriage.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I know how fond you were of him. And then you went off to Italy?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes; you see we had money then, and the doctors insisted on our going,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: so we started a month later.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And your husband came back quite well?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: As sound as a bell!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But—the doctor?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What doctor?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I thought your maid said the gentleman who arrived here just as I did,

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: was the doctor?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, that was Doctor Rank, but he doesn’t come here professionally. He

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is our greatest friend, and comes in at least once every day. No,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald has not had an hour’s illness since then, and our children are

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: strong and healthy and so am I. _[Jumps up and claps her hands.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine! Christine! it’s good to be alive and happy!—But how horrid

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of me; I am talking of nothing but my own affairs. _[Sits on a stool

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: near her, and rests her arms on her knees.]_ You mustn’t be angry with

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me. Tell me, is it really true that you did not love your husband? Why

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: did you marry him?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: My mother was alive then, and was bedridden and helpless, and I had to

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: provide for my two younger brothers; so I did not think I was justified

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: in refusing his offer.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, perhaps you were quite right. He was rich at that time, then?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I believe he was quite well off. But his business was a precarious one;

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: and, when he died, it all went to pieces and there was nothing left.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And then?—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Well, I had to turn my hand to anything I could find—first a small

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: shop, then a small school, and so on. The last three years have seemed

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: like one long working-day, with no rest. Now it is at an end, Nora. My

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: poor mother needs me no more, for she is gone; and the boys do not need

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: me either; they have got situations and can shift for themselves.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What a relief you must feel if—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, indeed; I only feel my life unspeakably empty. No one to live for

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: anymore. _[Gets up restlessly.]_ That was why I could not stand the

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: life in my little backwater any longer. I hope it may be easier here to

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: find something which will busy me and occupy my thoughts. If only I

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: could have the good luck to get some regular work—office work of some

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: kind—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But, Christine, that is so frightfully tiring, and you look tired out

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now. You had far better go away to some watering-place.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[walking to the window]_. I have no father to give me money for a

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: journey, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[rising]_. Oh, don’t be angry with me!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[going up to her]_. It is you that must not be angry with me, dear.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: The worst of a position like mine is that it makes one so bitter. No

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: one to work for, and yet obliged to be always on the lookout for

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: chances. One must live, and so one becomes selfish. When you told me of

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: the happy turn your fortunes have taken—you will hardly believe it—I

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: was delighted not so much on your account as on my own.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How do you mean?—Oh, I understand. You mean that perhaps Torvald could

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: get you something to do.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, that was what I was thinking of.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He must, Christine. Just leave it to me; I will broach the subject very

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: cleverly—I will think of something that will please him very much. It

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: will make me so happy to be of some use to you.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: How kind you are, Nora, to be so anxious to help me! It is doubly kind

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: in you, for you know so little of the burdens and troubles of life.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I—? I know so little of them?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[smiling]_. My dear! Small household cares and that sort of thing!—You

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: are a child, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[tosses her head and crosses the stage]_. You ought not to be so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: superior.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You are just like the others. They all think that I am incapable of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: anything really serious—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Come, come—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: —that I have gone through nothing in this world of cares.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But, my dear Nora, you have just told me all your troubles.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Pooh!—those were trifles. _[Lowering her voice.]_ I have not told you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the important thing.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: The important thing? What do you mean?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You look down upon me altogether, Christine—but you ought not to. You

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: are proud, aren’t you, of having worked so hard and so long for your

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: mother?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Indeed, I don’t look down on anyone. But it is true that I am both

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: proud and glad to think that I was privileged to make the end of my

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: mother’s life almost free from care.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And you are proud to think of what you have done for your brothers?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I think I have the right to be.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I think so, too. But now, listen to this; I too have something to be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: proud and glad of.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I have no doubt you have. But what do you refer to?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Speak low. Suppose Torvald were to hear! He mustn’t on any account—no

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: one in the world must know, Christine, except you.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But what is it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Come here. _[Pulls her down on the sofa beside her.]_ Now I will show

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you that I too have something to be proud and glad of. It was I who

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: saved Torvald’s life.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: “Saved”? How?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I told you about our trip to Italy. Torvald would never have recovered

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: if he had not gone there—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, but your father gave you the necessary funds.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[smiling]_. Yes, that is what Torvald and all the others think, but—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Papa didn’t give us a shilling. It was I who procured the money.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You? All that large sum?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Two hundred and fifty pounds. What do you think of that?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But, Nora, how could you possibly do it? Did you win a prize in the

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Lottery?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[contemptuously]_. In the Lottery? There would have been no credit in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: that.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But where did you get it from, then? Nora _[humming and smiling with an

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: air of mystery]_. Hm, hm! Aha!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Because you couldn’t have borrowed it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Couldn’t I? Why not?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, a wife cannot borrow without her husband’s consent.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[tossing her head]_. Oh, if it is a wife who has any head for

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: business—a wife who has the wit to be a little bit clever—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I don’t understand it at all, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: There is no need you should. I never said I had borrowed the money. I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: may have got it some other way. _[Lies back on the sofa.]_ Perhaps I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: got it from some other admirer. When anyone is as attractive as I am—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You are a mad creature.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Now, you know you’re full of curiosity, Christine.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Listen to me, Nora dear. Haven’t you been a little bit imprudent?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[sits up straight]_. Is it imprudent to save your husband’s life?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: It seems to me imprudent, without his knowledge, to—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But it was absolutely necessary that he should not know! My goodness,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: can’t you understand that? It was necessary he should have no idea what

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: a dangerous condition he was in. It was to me that the doctors came and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: said that his life was in danger, and that the only thing to save him

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: was to live in the south. Do you suppose I didn’t try, first of all, to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: get what I wanted as if it were for myself? I told him how much I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: should love to travel abroad like other young wives; I tried tears and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: entreaties with him; I told him that he ought to remember the condition

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I was in, and that he ought to be kind and indulgent to me; I even

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hinted that he might raise a loan. That nearly made him angry,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine. He said I was thoughtless, and that it was his duty as my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband not to indulge me in my whims and caprices—as I believe he

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: called them. Very well, I thought, you must be saved—and that was how I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: came to devise a way out of the difficulty—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And did your husband never get to know from your father that the money

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: had not come from him?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, never. Papa died just at that time. I had meant to let him into the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: secret and beg him never to reveal it. But he was so ill then—alas,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: there never was any need to tell him.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And since then have you never told your secret to your husband?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Good Heavens, no! How could you think so? A man who has such strong

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: opinions about these things! And besides, how painful and humiliating

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it would be for Torvald, with his manly independence, to know that he

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: owed me anything! It would upset our mutual relations altogether; our

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: beautiful happy home would no longer be what it is now.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Do you mean never to tell him about it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[meditatively, and with a half smile]_. Yes—someday, perhaps, after

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: many years, when I am no longer as nice-looking as I am now. Don’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: laugh at me! I mean, of course, when Torvald is no longer as devoted to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me as he is now; when my dancing and dressing-up and reciting have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: palled on him; then it may be a good thing to have something in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: reserve—_[Breaking off.]_ What nonsense! That time will never come.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Now, what do you think of my great secret, Christine? Do you still

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: think I am of no use? I can tell you, too, that this affair has caused

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me a lot of worry. It has been by no means easy for me to meet my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: engagements punctually. I may tell you that there is something that is

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: called, in business, quarterly interest, and another thing called

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: payment in installments, and it is always so dreadfully difficult to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: manage them. I have had to save a little here and there, where I could,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you understand. I have not been able to put aside much from my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: housekeeping money, for Torvald must have a good table. I couldn’t let

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: my children be shabbily dressed; I have felt obliged to use up all he

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: gave me for them, the sweet little darlings!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: So it has all had to come out of your own necessaries of life, poor

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Of course. Besides, I was the one responsible for it. Whenever Torvald

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: has given me money for new dresses and such things, I have never spent

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: more than half of it; I have always bought the simplest and cheapest

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: things. Thank Heaven, any clothes look well on me, and so Torvald has

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: never noticed it. But it was often very hard on me, Christine—because

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it is delightful to be really well dressed, isn’t it?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Quite so.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well, then I have found other ways of earning money. Last winter I was

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: lucky enough to get a lot of copying to do; so I locked myself up and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: sat writing every evening until quite late at night. Many a time I was

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: desperately tired; but all the same it was a tremendous pleasure to sit

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: there working and earning money. It was like being a man.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: How much have you been able to pay off in that way?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I can’t tell you exactly. You see, it is very difficult to keep an

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: account of a business matter of that kind. I only know that I have paid

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: every penny that I could scrape together. Many a time I was at my wits’

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: end. _[Smiles.]_ Then I used to sit here and imagine that a rich old

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: gentleman had fallen in love with me—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: What! Who was it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Be quiet!—that he had died; and that when his will was opened it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: contained, written in big letters, the instruction: “The lovely Mrs

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nora Helmer is to have all I possess paid over to her at once in cash.”

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But, my dear Nora—who could the man be?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Good gracious, can’t you understand? There was no old gentleman at all;

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it was only something that I used to sit here and imagine, when I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: couldn’t think of any way of procuring money. But it’s all the same

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now; the tiresome old person can stay where he is, as far as I am

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: concerned; I don’t care about him or his will either, for I am free

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: from care now. _[Jumps up.]_ My goodness, it’s delightful to think of,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine! Free from care! To be able to be free from care, quite free

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: from care; to be able to play and romp with the children; to be able to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: keep the house beautifully and have everything just as Torvald likes

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it! And, think of it, soon the spring will come and the big blue sky!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Perhaps we shall be able to take a little trip—perhaps I shall see the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: sea again! Oh, it’s a wonderful thing to be alive and be happy. _[A

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: bell is heard in the hall.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[rising]_. There is the bell; perhaps I had better go.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, don’t go; no one will come in here; it is sure to be for Torvald.

SPEAKER: SERVANT
TEXT: _[at the hall door]_. Excuse me, ma’am—there is a gentleman to see the

SPEAKER: SERVANT
TEXT: master, and as the doctor is with him—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Who is it?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[at the door]_. It is I, Mrs Helmer. _[Mrs LINDE starts, trembles, and

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: turns to the window.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[takes a step towards him, and speaks in a strained, low voice]_. You?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What is it? What do you want to see my husband about?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Bank business—in a way. I have a small post in the Bank, and I hear

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: your husband is to be our chief now—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Then it is—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Nothing but dry business matters, Mrs Helmer; absolutely nothing else.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Be so good as to go into the study, then. _[She bows indifferently to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: him and shuts the door into the hall; then comes back and makes up the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: fire in the stove.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora—who was that man?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: A lawyer, of the name of Krogstad.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Then it really was he.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do you know the man?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I used to—many years ago. At one time he was a solicitor’s clerk in our

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: town.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, he was.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: He is greatly altered.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He made a very unhappy marriage.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: He is a widower now, isn’t he?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: With several children. There now, it is burning up. [Shuts the door of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the stove and moves the rocking-chair aside.]

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: They say he carries on various kinds of business.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Really! Perhaps he does; I don’t know anything about it. But don’t let

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: us think of business; it is so tiresome.

SPEAKER: DOCTOR RANK
TEXT: _[comes out of HELMER’S study. Before he shuts the door he calls to

SPEAKER: DOCTOR RANK
TEXT: him]_. No, my dear fellow, I won’t disturb you; I would rather go in to

SPEAKER: DOCTOR RANK
TEXT: your wife for a little while. _[Shuts the door and sees Mrs LINDE.]_ I

SPEAKER: DOCTOR RANK
TEXT: beg your pardon; I am afraid I am disturbing you too.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, not at all. _[Introducing him]_. Doctor Rank, Mrs Linde.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I have often heard Mrs Linde’s name mentioned here. I think I passed

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: you on the stairs when I arrived, Mrs Linde?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, I go up very slowly; I can’t manage stairs well.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Ah! some slight internal weakness?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, the fact is I have been overworking myself.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Nothing more than that? Then I suppose you have come to town to amuse

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: yourself with our entertainments?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I have come to look for work.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Is that a good cure for overwork?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: One must live, Doctor Rank.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, the general opinion seems to be that it is necessary.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Look here, Doctor Rank—you know you want to live.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Certainly. However wretched I may feel, I want to prolong the agony as

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: long as possible. All my patients are like that. And so are those who

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: are morally diseased; one of them, and a bad case too, is at this very

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: moment with Helmer—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[sadly]_. Ah!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Whom do you mean?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: A lawyer of the name of Krogstad, a fellow you don’t know at all. He

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: suffers from a diseased moral character, Mrs Helmer; but even he began

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: talking of its being highly important that he should live.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Did he? What did he want to speak to Torvald about?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I have no idea; I only heard that it was something about the Bank.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I didn’t know this—what’s his name—Krogstad had anything to do with the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Bank.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, he has some sort of appointment there. _[To Mrs Linde.]_ I don’t

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: know whether you find also in your part of the world that there are

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: certain people who go zealously snuffing about to smell out moral

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: corruption, and, as soon as they have found some, put the person

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: concerned into some lucrative position where they can keep their eye on

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: him. Healthy natures are left out in the cold.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Still I think the sick are those who most need taking care of.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[shrugging his shoulders]_. Yes, there you are. That is the sentiment

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: that is turning Society into a sick-house.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[NORA, who has been absorbed in her thoughts, breaks out into

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: smothered laughter and claps her hands.]_

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Why do you laugh at that? Have you any notion what Society really is?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do I care about tiresome Society? I am laughing at something quite

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: different, something extremely amusing. Tell me, Doctor Rank, are all

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the people who are employed in the Bank dependent on Torvald now?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Is that what you find so extremely amusing?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[smiling and humming]_. That’s my affair! _[Walking about the room.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It’s perfectly glorious to think that we have—that Torvald has so much

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: power over so many people. _[Takes the packet from her pocket.]_ Doctor

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Rank, what do you say to a macaroon?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: What, macaroons? I thought they were forbidden here.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, but these are some Christine gave me.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: What! I?—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, well, don’t be alarmed! You couldn’t know that Torvald had

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: forbidden them. I must tell you that he is afraid they will spoil my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: teeth. But, bah!—once in a way—That’s so, isn’t it, Doctor Rank? By

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: your leave! _[Puts a macaroon into his mouth.]_ You must have one too,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine. And I shall have one, just a little one—or at most two.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Walking about.]_ I am tremendously happy. There is just one thing in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the world now that I should dearly love to do.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, what is that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It’s something I should dearly love to say, if Torvald could hear me.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, why can’t you say it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I daren’t; it’s so shocking.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Shocking?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, I should not advise you to say it. Still, with us you might. What

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: is it you would so much like to say if Torvald could hear you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I should just love to say—Well, I’m damned!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Are you mad?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora, dear—!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Say it, here he is!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[hiding the packet]_. Hush! Hush! Hush! _[HELMER comes out of his

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: room, with his coat over his arm and his hat in his hand.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well, Torvald dear, have you got rid of him?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, he has just gone.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Let me introduce you—this is Christine, who has come to town.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Christine—? Excuse me, but I don’t know—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Mrs Linde, dear; Christine Linde.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Of course. A school friend of my wife’s, I presume?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, we have known each other since then.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And just think, she has taken a long journey in order to see you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, really, I—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine is tremendously clever at book-keeping, and she is

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: frightfully anxious to work under some clever man, so as to perfect

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: herself—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Very sensible, Mrs Linde.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And when she heard you had been appointed manager of the Bank—the news

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: was telegraphed, you know—she travelled here as quick as she could.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald, I am sure you will be able to do something for Christine, for

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: my sake, won’t you?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well, it is not altogether impossible. I presume you are a widow, Mrs

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Linde?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And have had some experience of book-keeping?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, a fair amount.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Ah! well, it’s very likely I may be able to find something for you—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[clapping her hands]_. What did I tell you? What did I tell you?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You have just come at a fortunate moment, Mrs Linde.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: How am I to thank you?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There is no need. _[Puts on his coat.]_ But today you must excuse me—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Wait a minute; I will come with you. _[Brings his fur coat from the

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: hall and warms it at the fire.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Don’t be long away, Torvald dear.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: About an hour, not more.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Are you going too, Christine?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[putting on her cloak]_. Yes, I must go and look for a room.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Oh, well then, we can walk down the street together.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[helping her]_. What a pity it is we are so short of space here; I am

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: afraid it is impossible for us—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Please don’t think of it! Goodbye, Nora dear, and many thanks.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Goodbye for the present. Of course you will come back this evening. And

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you too, Dr. Rank. What do you say? If you are well enough? Oh, you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: must be! Wrap yourself up well. _[They go to the door all talking

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: together. Children’s voices are heard on the staircase.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: There they are! There they are! _[She runs to open the door. The NURSE

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: comes in with the children.]_ Come in! Come in! _[Stoops and kisses

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: them.]_ Oh, you sweet blessings! Look at them, Christine! Aren’t they

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: darlings?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Don’t let us stand here in the draught.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Come along, Mrs Linde; the place will only be bearable for a mother

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: now!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[RANK, HELMER, and Mrs Linde go downstairs. The NURSE comes forward

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: with the children; NORA shuts the hall door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How fresh and well you look! Such red cheeks like apples and roses.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[The children all talk at once while she speaks to them.]_ Have you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: had great fun? That’s splendid! What, you pulled both Emmy and Bob

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: along on the sledge? —both at once?—that was good. You are a clever

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: boy, Ivar. Let me take her for a little, Anne. My sweet little baby

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: doll! _[Takes the baby from the MAID and dances it up and down.]_ Yes,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: yes, mother will dance with Bob too. What! Have you been snowballing? I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: wish I had been there too! No, no, I will take their things off, Anne;

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: please let me do it, it is such fun. Go in now, you look half frozen.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: There is some hot coffee for you on the stove.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[The NURSE goes into the room on the left. NORA takes off the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: children’s things and throws them about, while they all talk to her at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: once.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Really! Did a big dog run after you? But it didn’t bite you? No, dogs

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: don’t bite nice little dolly children. You mustn’t look at the parcels,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Ivar. What are they? Ah, I daresay you would like to know. No, no—it’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: something nasty! Come, let us have a game! What shall we play at? Hide

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and Seek? Yes, we’ll play Hide and Seek. Bob shall hide first. Must I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hide? Very well, I’ll hide first. _[She and the children laugh and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: shout, and romp in and out of the room; at last NORA hides under the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: table, the children rush in and out for her, but do not see her; they

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hear her smothered laughter, run to the table, lift up the cloth and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: find her. Shouts of laughter. She crawls forward and pretends to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: frighten them. Fresh laughter. Meanwhile there has been a knock at the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hall door, but none of them has noticed it. The door is half opened,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and KROGSTAD appears, he waits a little; the game goes on.]_

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Excuse me, Mrs Helmer.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[with a stifled cry, turns round and gets up on to her knees]_. Ah!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: what do you want?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Excuse me, the outer door was ajar; I suppose someone forgot to shut

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[rising]_. My husband is out, Mr. Krogstad.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I know that.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you want here, then?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: A word with you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: With me?—_[To the children, gently.]_ Go in to nurse. What? No, the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: strange man won’t do mother any harm. When he has gone we will have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: another game. _[She takes the children into the room on the left, and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: shuts the door after them.]_ You want to speak to me?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Yes, I do.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Today? It is not the first of the month yet.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: No, it is Christmas Eve, and it will depend on yourself what sort of a

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Christmas you will spend.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean? Today it is absolutely impossible for me—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: We won’t talk about that until later on. This is something different. I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: presume you can give me a moment?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes—yes, I can—although—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Good. I was in Olsen’s Restaurant and saw your husband going down the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: street—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: With a lady.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What then?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: May I make so bold as to ask if it was a Mrs Linde?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Just arrived in town?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, today.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: She is a great friend of yours, isn’t she?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: She is. But I don’t see—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I knew her too, once upon a time.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am aware of that.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Are you? So you know all about it; I thought as much. Then I can ask

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you, without beating about the bush—is Mrs Linde to have an appointment

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: in the Bank?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What right have you to question me, Mr. Krogstad?—You, one of my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband’s subordinates! But since you ask, you shall know. Yes, Mrs

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Linde is to have an appointment. And it was I who pleaded her cause,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Mr. Krogstad, let me tell you that.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I was right in what I thought, then.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[walking up and down the stage]_. Sometimes one has a tiny little bit

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of influence, I should hope. Because one is a woman, it does not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: necessarily follow that—. When anyone is in a subordinate position, Mr.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Krogstad, they should really be careful to avoid offending anyone

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: who—who—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Who has influence?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Exactly.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[changing his tone]_. Mrs Helmer, you will be so good as to use your

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: influence on my behalf.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What? What do you mean?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: You will be so kind as to see that I am allowed to keep my subordinate

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: position in the Bank.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean by that? Who proposes to take your post away from you?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Oh, there is no necessity to keep up the pretence of ignorance. I can

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: quite understand that your friend is not very anxious to expose herself

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: to the chance of rubbing shoulders with me; and I quite understand,

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: too, whom I have to thank for being turned off.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But I assure you—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Very likely; but, to come to the point, the time has come when I should

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: advise you to use your influence to prevent that.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But, Mr. Krogstad, I have no influence.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Haven’t you? I thought you said yourself just now—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Naturally I did not mean you to put that construction on it. I! What

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: should make you think I have any influence of that kind with my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Oh, I have known your husband from our student days. I don’t suppose he

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: is any more unassailable than other husbands.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If you speak slightingly of my husband, I shall turn you out of the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: house.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: You are bold, Mrs Helmer.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am not afraid of you any longer. As soon as the New Year comes, I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: shall in a very short time be free of the whole thing.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[controlling himself]_. Listen to me, Mrs Helmer. If necessary, I am

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: prepared to fight for my small post in the Bank as if I were fighting

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: for my life.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: So it seems.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: It is not only for the sake of the money; indeed, that weighs least

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: with me in the matter. There is another reason—well, I may as well tell

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you. My position is this. I daresay you know, like everybody else, that

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: once, many years ago, I was guilty of an indiscretion.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I think I have heard something of the kind.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: The matter never came into court; but every way seemed to be closed to

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: me after that. So I took to the business that you know of. I had to do

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: something; and, honestly, I don’t think I’ve been one of the worst. But

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: now I must cut myself free from all that. My sons are growing up; for

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: their sake I must try and win back as much respect as I can in the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: town. This post in the Bank was like the first step up for me—and now

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: your husband is going to kick me downstairs again into the mud.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But you must believe me, Mr. Krogstad; it is not in my power to help

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you at all.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Then it is because you haven’t the will; but I have means to compel

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You don’t mean that you will tell my husband that I owe you money?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Hm!—suppose I were to tell him?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It would be perfectly infamous of you. _[Sobbing.]_ To think of his

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: learning my secret, which has been my joy and pride, in such an ugly,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: clumsy way—that he should learn it from you! And it would put me in a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: horribly disagreeable position—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Only disagreeable?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[impetuously]_. Well, do it, then!—and it will be the worse for you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: My husband will see for himself what a blackguard you are, and you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: certainly won’t keep your post then.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I asked you if it was only a disagreeable scene at home that you were

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: afraid of?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If my husband does get to know of it, of course he will at once pay you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: what is still owing, and we shall have nothing more to do with you.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[coming a step nearer]_. Listen to me, Mrs Helmer. Either you have a

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: very bad memory or you know very little of business. I shall be obliged

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: to remind you of a few details.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: When your husband was ill, you came to me to borrow two hundred and

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: fifty pounds.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I didn’t know anyone else to go to.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I promised to get you that amount—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, and you did so.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I promised to get you that amount, on certain conditions. Your mind was

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: so taken up with your husband’s illness, and you were so anxious to get

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: the money for your journey, that you seem to have paid no attention to

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: the conditions of our bargain. Therefore it will not be amiss if I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: remind you of them. Now, I promised to get the money on the security of

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: a bond which I drew up.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, and which I signed.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Good. But below your signature there were a few lines constituting your

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: father a surety for the money; those lines your father should have

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: signed.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Should? He did sign them.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I had left the date blank; that is to say, your father should himself

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: have inserted the date on which he signed the paper. Do you remember

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I think I remember—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Then I gave you the bond to send by post to your father. Is that not

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: so?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: And you naturally did so at once, because five or six days afterwards

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you brought me the bond with your father’s signature. And then I gave

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you the money.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well, haven’t I been paying it off regularly?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Fairly so, yes. But—to come back to the matter in hand—that must have

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: been a very trying time for you, Mrs Helmer?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was, indeed.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Your father was very ill, wasn’t he?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He was very near his end.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: And died soon afterwards?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Tell me, Mrs Helmer, can you by any chance remember what day your

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: father died?—on what day of the month, I mean.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Papa died on the 29th of September.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: That is correct; I have ascertained it for myself. And, as that is so,

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: there is a discrepancy _[taking a paper from his pocket]_ which I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: cannot account for.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What discrepancy? I don’t know—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: The discrepancy consists, Mrs Helmer, in the fact that your father

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: signed this bond three days after his death.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean? I don’t understand—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Your father died on the 29th of September. But, look here; your father

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: has dated his signature the 2nd of October. It is a discrepancy, isn’t

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: it? _[NORA is silent.]_ Can you explain it to me? _[NORA is still

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: silent.]_ It is a remarkable thing, too, that the words “2nd of

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: October,” as well as the year, are not written in your father’s

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: handwriting but in one that I think I know. Well, of course it can be

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: explained; your father may have forgotten to date his signature, and

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: someone else may have dated it haphazard before they knew of his death.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: There is no harm in that. It all depends on the signature of the name;

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: and that is genuine, I suppose, Mrs Helmer? It was your father himself

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: who signed his name here?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[after a short pause, throws her head up and looks defiantly at him]_.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, it was not. It was I that wrote papa’s name.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Are you aware that is a dangerous confession?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: In what way? You shall have your money soon.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Let me ask you a question; why did you not send the paper to your

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: father?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was impossible; papa was so ill. If I had asked him for his

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: signature, I should have had to tell him what the money was to be used

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: for; and when he was so ill himself I couldn’t tell him that my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband’s life was in danger—it was impossible.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: It would have been better for you if you had given up your trip abroad.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, that was impossible. That trip was to save my husband’s life; I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: couldn’t give that up.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: But did it never occur to you that you were committing a fraud on me?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I couldn’t take that into account; I didn’t trouble myself about you at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: all. I couldn’t bear you, because you put so many heartless

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: difficulties in my way, although you knew what a dangerous condition my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband was in.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Mrs Helmer, you evidently do not realise clearly what it is that you

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: have been guilty of. But I can assure you that my one false step, which

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: lost me all my reputation, was nothing more or nothing worse than what

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you have done.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You? Do you ask me to believe that you were brave enough to run a risk

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: to save your wife’s life?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: The law cares nothing about motives.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Then it must be a very foolish law.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Foolish or not, it is the law by which you will be judged, if I produce

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: this paper in court.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I don’t believe it. Is a daughter not to be allowed to spare her dying

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: father anxiety and care? Is a wife not to be allowed to save her

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband’s life? I don’t know much about law; but I am certain that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: there must be laws permitting such things as that. Have you no

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: knowledge of such laws—you who are a lawyer? You must be a very poor

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: lawyer, Mr. Krogstad.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Maybe. But matters of business—such business as you and I have had

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: together—do you think I don’t understand that? Very well. Do as you

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: please. But let me tell you this—if I lose my position a second time,

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you shall lose yours with me. _[He bows, and goes out through the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: hall.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[appears buried in thought for a short time, then tosses her head]_.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nonsense! Trying to frighten me like that!—I am not so silly as he

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: thinks. _[Begins to busy herself putting the children’s things in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: order.]_ And yet—? No, it’s impossible! I did it for love’s sake.

SPEAKER: THE CHILDREN
TEXT: _[in the doorway on the left]_. Mother, the stranger man has gone out

SPEAKER: THE CHILDREN
TEXT: through the gate.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, dears, I know. But, don’t tell anyone about the stranger man. Do

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you hear? Not even papa.

SPEAKER: CHILDREN
TEXT: No, mother; but will you come and play again?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no,—not now.

SPEAKER: CHILDREN
TEXT: But, mother, you promised us.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, but I can’t now. Run away in; I have such a lot to do. Run away

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: in, my sweet little darlings. _[She gets them into the room by degrees

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and shuts the door on them; then sits down on the sofa, takes up a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: piece of needlework and sews a few stitches, but soon stops.]_ No!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Throws down the work, gets up, goes to the hall door and calls out.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Helen! bring the Tree in. _[Goes to the table on the left, opens a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: drawer, and stops again.]_ No, no! it is quite impossible!

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: _[coming in with the Tree]_. Where shall I put it, ma’am?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Here, in the middle of the floor.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Shall I get you anything else?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, thank you. I have all I want. [Exit MAID.]

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[begins dressing the tree]_. A candle here-and flowers here—The

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: horrible man! It’s all nonsense—there’s nothing wrong. The tree shall

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: be splendid! I will do everything I can think of to please you,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald!—I will sing for you, dance for you—_[HELMER comes in with some

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: papers under his arm.]_ Oh! are you back already?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes. Has anyone been here?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Here? No.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That is strange. I saw Krogstad going out of the gate.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Did you? Oh yes, I forgot, Krogstad was here for a moment.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, I can see from your manner that he has been here begging you to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: say a good word for him.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And you were to appear to do it of your own accord; you were to conceal

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: from me the fact of his having been here; didn’t he beg that of you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: too?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, Torvald, but—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, Nora, and you would be a party to that sort of thing? To have any

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: talk with a man like that, and give him any sort of promise? And to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: tell me a lie into the bargain?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: A lie—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Didn’t you tell me no one had been here? _[Shakes his finger at her.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My little songbird must never do that again. A songbird must have a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: clean beak to chirp with—no false notes! _[Puts his arm round her

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: waist.]_ That is so, isn’t it? Yes, I am sure it is. _[Lets her go.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: We will say no more about it. _[Sits down by the stove.]_ How warm and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: snug it is here! _[Turns over his papers.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[after a short pause, during which she busies herself with the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christmas Tree.]_ Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am looking forward tremendously to the fancy-dress ball at the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Stenborgs’ the day after tomorrow.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And I am tremendously curious to see what you are going to surprise me

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: with.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was very silly of me to want to do that.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I can’t hit upon anything that will do; everything I think of seems so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: silly and insignificant.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Does my little Nora acknowledge that at last?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[standing behind his chair with her arms on the back of it]_. Are you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: very busy, Torvald?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What are all those papers?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Bank business.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Already?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I have got authority from the retiring manager to undertake the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: necessary changes in the staff and in the rearrangement of the work;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and I must make use of the Christmas week for that, so as to have

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: everything in order for the new year.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Then that was why this poor Krogstad—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Hm!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[leans against the back of his chair and strokes his hair]_. If you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hadn’t been so busy I should have asked you a tremendously big favour,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What is that? Tell me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: There is no one has such good taste as you. And I do so want to look

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: nice at the fancy-dress ball. Torvald, couldn’t you take me in hand and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: decide what I shall go as, and what sort of a dress I shall wear?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Aha! so my obstinate little woman is obliged to get someone to come to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: her rescue?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, Torvald, I can’t get along a bit without your help.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Very well, I will think it over, we shall manage to hit upon something.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That is nice of you. _[Goes to the Christmas Tree. A short pause.]_ How

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: pretty the red flowers look—. But, tell me, was it really something

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: very bad that this Krogstad was guilty of?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: He forged someone’s name. Have you any idea what that means?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Isn’t it possible that he was driven to do it by necessity?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes; or, as in so many cases, by imprudence. I am not so heartless as

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: to condemn a man altogether because of a single false step of that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: kind.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, you wouldn’t, would you, Torvald?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Many a man has been able to retrieve his character, if he has openly

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: confessed his fault and taken his punishment.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Punishment—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But Krogstad did nothing of that sort; he got himself out of it by a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: cunning trick, and that is why he has gone under altogether.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But do you think it would—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Just think how a guilty man like that has to lie and play the hypocrite

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: with every one, how he has to wear a mask in the presence of those near

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and dear to him, even before his own wife and children. And about the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: children—that is the most terrible part of it all, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Because such an atmosphere of lies infects and poisons the whole life

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: of a home. Each breath the children take in such a house is full of the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: germs of evil.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[coming nearer him]_. Are you sure of that?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My dear, I have often seen it in the course of my life as a lawyer.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Almost everyone who has gone to the bad early in life has had a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: deceitful mother.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Why do you only say—mother?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It seems most commonly to be the mother’s influence, though naturally a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: bad father’s would have the same result. Every lawyer is familiar with

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: the fact. This Krogstad, now, has been persistently poisoning his own

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: children with lies and dissimulation; that is why I say he has lost all

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: moral character. _[Holds out his hands to her.]_ That is why my sweet

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: little Nora must promise me not to plead his cause. Give me your hand

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: on it. Come, come, what is this? Give me your hand. There now, that’s

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: settled. I assure you it would be quite impossible for me to work with

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: him; I literally feel physically ill when I am in the company of such

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: people.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[takes her hand out of his and goes to the opposite side of the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christmas Tree]_. How hot it is in here; and I have such a lot to do.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[getting up and putting his papers in order]_. Yes, and I must try and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: read through some of these before dinner; and I must think about your

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: costume, too. And it is just possible I may have something ready in

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: gold paper to hang up on the Tree. _[Puts his hand on her head.]_ My

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: precious little singing-bird! _[He goes into his room and shuts the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: door after him.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[after a pause, whispers]_. No, no—it isn’t true. It’s impossible; it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: must be impossible.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[The NURSE opens the door on the left.]_

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: The little ones are begging so hard to be allowed to come in to mamma.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no, no! Don’t let them come in to me! You stay with them, Anne.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: Very well, ma’am. _[Shuts the door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[pale with terror]_. Deprave my little children? Poison my home? _[A

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: short pause. Then she tosses her head.]_ It’s not true. It can’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: possibly be true.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: ACT II

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[THE SAME SCENE.—THE Christmas Tree is in the corner by the piano,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: stripped of its ornaments and with burnt-down candle-ends on its

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: dishevelled branches. NORA’S cloak and hat are lying on the sofa. She

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is alone in the room, walking about uneasily. She stops by the sofa and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: takes up her cloak.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[drops her cloak]_. Someone is coming now! _[Goes to the door and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: listens.]_ No—it is no one. Of course, no one will come today,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christmas Day—nor tomorrow either. But, perhaps—_[opens the door and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: looks out]_. No, nothing in the letterbox; it is quite empty. _[Comes

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: forward.]_ What rubbish! of course he can’t be in earnest about it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Such a thing couldn’t happen; it is impossible—I have three little

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: children.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Enter the NURSE from the room on the left, carrying a big cardboard

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: box.]_

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: At last I have found the box with the fancy dress.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Thanks; put it on the table.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: _[doing so]_. But it is very much in want of mending.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I should like to tear it into a hundred thousand pieces.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: What an idea! It can easily be put in order—just a little patience.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I will go and get Mrs Linde to come and help me with it.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: What, out again? In this horrible weather? You will catch cold, ma’am,

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: and make yourself ill.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well, worse than that might happen. How are the children?

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: The poor little souls are playing with their Christmas presents, but—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do they ask much for me?

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: You see, they are so accustomed to have their mamma with them.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, but, nurse, I shall not be able to be so much with them now as I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: was before.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: Oh well, young children easily get accustomed to anything.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do you think so? Do you think they would forget their mother if she

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: went away altogether?

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: Good heavens!—went away altogether?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nurse, I want you to tell me something I have often wondered about—how

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: could you have the heart to put your own child out among strangers?

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: I was obliged to, if I wanted to be little Nora’s nurse.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, but how could you be willing to do it?

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: What, when I was going to get such a good place by it? A poor girl who

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: has got into trouble should be glad to. Besides, that wicked man didn’t

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: do a single thing for me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But I suppose your daughter has quite forgotten you.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: No, indeed she hasn’t. She wrote to me when she was confirmed, and when

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: she was married.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting her arms round her neck]_. Dear old Anne, you were a good

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: mother to me when I was little.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: Little Nora, poor dear, had no other mother but me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And if my little ones had no other mother, I am sure you would—What

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: nonsense I am talking! _[Opens the box.]_ Go in to them. Now I must—.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You will see tomorrow how charming I shall look.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: I am sure there will be no one at the ball so charming as you, ma’am.

SPEAKER: NURSE
TEXT: _[Goes into the room on the left.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[begins to unpack the box, but soon pushes it away from her]_. If only

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I dared go out. If only no one would come. If only I could be sure

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: nothing would happen here in the meantime. Stuff and nonsense! No one

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: will come. Only I mustn’t think about it. I will brush my muff. What

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: lovely, lovely gloves! Out of my thoughts, out of my thoughts! One,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: two, three, four, five, six— _[Screams.]_ Ah! there is someone coming—.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Makes a movement towards the door, but stands irresolute.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Enter Mrs Linde from the hall, where she has taken off her cloak and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hat.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, it’s you, Christine. There is no one else out there, is there? How

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: good of you to come!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I heard you were up asking for me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I was passing by. As a matter of fact, it is something you could

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: help me with. Let us sit down here on the sofa. Look here. Tomorrow

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: evening there is to be a fancy-dress ball at the Stenborgs’, who live

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: above us; and Torvald wants me to go as a Neapolitan fisher-girl, and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: dance the Tarantella that I learned at Capri.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I see; you are going to keep up the character.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, Torvald wants me to. Look, here is the dress; Torvald had it made

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: for me there, but now it is all so torn, and I haven’t any idea—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: We will easily put that right. It is only some of the trimming come

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: unsewn here and there. Needle and thread? Now then, that’s all we want.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is nice of you.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[sewing]_. So you are going to be dressed up tomorrow Nora. I will

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: tell you what—I shall come in for a moment and see you in your fine

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: feathers. But I have completely forgotten to thank you for a delightful
