SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: evening yesterday.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[gets up, and crosses the stage]_. Well, I don’t think yesterday was

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: as pleasant as usual. You ought to have come to town a little earlier,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine. Certainly Torvald does understand how to make a house dainty

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and attractive.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And so do you, it seems to me; you are not your father’s daughter for

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: nothing. But tell me, is Doctor Rank always as depressed as he was

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: yesterday?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No; yesterday it was very noticeable. I must tell you that he suffers

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: from a very dangerous disease. He has consumption of the spine, poor

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: creature. His father was a horrible man who committed all sorts of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: excesses; and that is why his son was sickly from childhood, do you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: understand?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[dropping her sewing]_. But, my dearest Nora, how do you know anything

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: about such things?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[walking about]_. Pooh! When you have three children, you get visits

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now and then from—from married women, who know something of medical

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: matters, and they talk about one thing and another.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[goes on sewing. A short silence]_. Does Doctor Rank come here

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: everyday?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Everyday regularly. He is Torvald’s most intimate friend, and a great

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: friend of mine too. He is just like one of the family.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But tell me this—is he perfectly sincere? I mean, isn’t he the kind of

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: man that is very anxious to make himself agreeable?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Not in the least. What makes you think that?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: When you introduced him to me yesterday, he declared he had often heard

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: my name mentioned in this house; but afterwards I noticed that your

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: husband hadn’t the slightest idea who I was. So how could Doctor Rank—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That is quite right, Christine. Torvald is so absurdly fond of me that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: he wants me absolutely to himself, as he says. At first he used to seem

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: almost jealous if I mentioned any of the dear folk at home, so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: naturally I gave up doing so. But I often talk about such things with

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Doctor Rank, because he likes hearing about them.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Listen to me, Nora. You are still very like a child in many things, and

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I am older than you in many ways and have a little more experience. Let

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: me tell you this—you ought to make an end of it with Doctor Rank.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What ought I to make an end of?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Of two things, I think. Yesterday you talked some nonsense about a rich

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: admirer who was to leave you money—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: An admirer who doesn’t exist, unfortunately! But what then?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Is Doctor Rank a man of means?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, he is.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And has no one to provide for?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no one; but—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And comes here everyday?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I told you so.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But how can this well-bred man be so tactless?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I don’t understand you at all.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Don’t prevaricate, Nora. Do you suppose I don’t guess who lent you the

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: two hundred and fifty pounds?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Are you out of your senses? How can you think of such a thing! A friend

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of ours, who comes here everyday! Do you realise what a horribly

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: painful position that would be?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Then it really isn’t he?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, certainly not. It would never have entered into my head for a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: moment. Besides, he had no money to lend then; he came into his money

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: afterwards.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Well, I think that was lucky for you, my dear Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, it would never have come into my head to ask Doctor Rank. Although

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am quite sure that if I had asked him—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But of course you won’t.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Of course not. I have no reason to think it could possibly be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: necessary. But I am quite sure that if I told Doctor Rank—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Behind your husband’s back?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I must make an end of it with the other one, and that will be behind

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: his back too. I must make an end of it with him.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, that is what I told you yesterday, but—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[walking up and down]_. A man can put a thing like that straight much

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: easier than a woman—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: One’s husband, yes.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nonsense! _[Standing still.]_ When you pay off a debt you get your bond

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: back, don’t you?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, as a matter of course.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And can tear it into a hundred thousand pieces, and burn it up—the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: nasty dirty paper!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[looks hard at her, lays down her sewing and gets up slowly]_. Nora,

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: you are concealing something from me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do I look as if I were?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Something has happened to you since yesterday morning. Nora, what is

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going nearer to her]_. Christine! _[Listens.]_ Hush! there’s Torvald

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: come home. Do you mind going in to the children for the present?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald can’t bear to see dressmaking going on. Let Anne help you.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[gathering some of the things together]_. Certainly—but I am not going

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: away from here until we have had it out with one another. _[She goes

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: into the room on the left, as HELMER comes in from the hall.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going up to HELMER]_. I have wanted you so much, Torvald dear.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Was that the dressmaker?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, it was Christine; she is helping me to put my dress in order. You

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: will see I shall look quite smart.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Wasn’t that a happy thought of mine, now?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Splendid! But don’t you think it is nice of me, too, to do as you wish?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nice?—because you do as your husband wishes? Well, well, you little

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: rogue, I am sure you did not mean it in that way. But I am not going to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: disturb you; you will want to be trying on your dress, I expect.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I suppose you are going to work.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes. _[Shows her a bundle of papers.]_ Look at that. I have just been

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: into the bank. _[Turns to go into his room.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If your little squirrel were to ask you for something very, very

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: prettily—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What then?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Would you do it?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I should like to hear what it is, first.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Your squirrel would run about and do all her tricks if you would be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: nice, and do what she wants.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Speak plainly.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Your skylark would chirp about in every room, with her song rising and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: falling—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well, my skylark does that anyhow.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I would play the fairy and dance for you in the moonlight, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora—you surely don’t mean that request you made to me this morning?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going near him]_. Yes, Torvald, I beg you so earnestly—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Have you really the courage to open up that question again?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, dear, you must do as I ask; you must let Krogstad keep his post in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the bank.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My dear Nora, it is his post that I have arranged Mrs Linde shall have.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, you have been awfully kind about that; but you could just as well

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: dismiss some other clerk instead of Krogstad.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: This is simply incredible obstinacy! Because you chose to give him a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: thoughtless promise that you would speak for him, I am expected to—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That isn’t the reason, Torvald. It is for your own sake. This fellow

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: writes in the most scurrilous newspapers; you have told me so yourself.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He can do you an unspeakable amount of harm. I am frightened to death

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of him—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Ah, I understand; it is recollections of the past that scare you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Naturally you are thinking of your father.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes—yes, of course. Just recall to your mind what these malicious

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: creatures wrote in the papers about papa, and how horribly they

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: slandered him. I believe they would have procured his dismissal if the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Department had not sent you over to inquire into it, and if you had not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: been so kindly disposed and helpful to him.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My little Nora, there is an important difference between your father

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and me. Your father’s reputation as a public official was not above

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: suspicion. Mine is, and I hope it will continue to be so, as long as I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: hold my office.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You never can tell what mischief these men may contrive. We ought to be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: so well off, so snug and happy here in our peaceful home, and have no

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: cares—you and I and the children, Torvald! That is why I beg you so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: earnestly—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And it is just by interceding for him that you make it impossible for

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: me to keep him. It is already known at the Bank that I mean to dismiss

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Krogstad. Is it to get about now that the new manager has changed his

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: mind at his wife’s bidding—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And what if it did?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Of course!—if only this obstinate little person can get her way! Do you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: suppose I am going to make myself ridiculous before my whole staff, to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: let people think that I am a man to be swayed by all sorts of outside

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: influence? I should very soon feel the consequences of it, I can tell

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you! And besides, there is one thing that makes it quite impossible for

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: me to have Krogstad in the Bank as long as I am manager.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Whatever is that?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: His moral failings I might perhaps have overlooked, if necessary—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, you could—couldn’t you?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And I hear he is a good worker, too. But I knew him when we were boys.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It was one of those rash friendships that so often prove an incubus in

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: afterlife. I may as well tell you plainly, we were once on very

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: intimate terms with one another. But this tactless fellow lays no

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: restraint on himself when other people are present. On the contrary, he

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: thinks it gives him the right to adopt a familiar tone with me, and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: every minute it is “I say, Helmer, old fellow!” and that sort of thing.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I assure you it is extremely painful for me. He would make my position

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: in the Bank intolerable.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald, I don’t believe you mean that.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Don’t you? Why not?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Because it is such a narrow-minded way of looking at things.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What are you saying? Narrow-minded? Do you think I am narrow-minded?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, just the opposite, dear—and it is exactly for that reason.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It’s the same thing. You say my point of view is narrow-minded, so I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: must be so too. Narrow-minded! Very well—I must put an end to this.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[Goes to the hall door and calls.]_ Helen!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What are you going to do?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[looking among his papers]_. Settle it. _[Enter MAID.]_ Look here;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: take this letter and go downstairs with it at once. Find a messenger

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and tell him to deliver it, and be quick. The address is on it, and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: here is the money.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Very well, sir. _[Exit with the letter.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[putting his papers together]_. Now then, little Miss Obstinate.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[breathlessly]_. Torvald—what was that letter?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Krogstad’s dismissal.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Call her back, Torvald! There is still time. Oh Torvald, call her back!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Do it for my sake—for your own sake—for the children’s sake! Do you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hear me, Torvald? Call her back! You don’t know what that letter can

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: bring upon us.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It’s too late.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, it’s too late.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My dear Nora, I can forgive the anxiety you are in, although really it

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: is an insult to me. It is, indeed. Isn’t it an insult to think that I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: should be afraid of a starving quill-driver’s vengeance? But I forgive

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you nevertheless, because it is such eloquent witness to your great

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: love for me. _[Takes her in his arms.]_ And that is as it should be, my

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: own darling Nora. Come what will, you may be sure I shall have both

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: courage and strength if they be needed. You will see I am man enough to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: take everything upon myself.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[in a horror-stricken voice]_. What do you mean by that?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Everything, I say—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[recovering herself]_. You will never have to do that.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That’s right. Well, we will share it, Nora, as man and wife should.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That is how it shall be. _[Caressing her.]_ Are you content now? There!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There!—not these frightened dove’s eyes! The whole thing is only the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: wildest fancy!—Now, you must go and play through the Tarantella and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: practise with your tambourine. I shall go into the inner office and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: shut the door, and I shall hear nothing; you can make as much noise as

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you please. _[Turns back at the door.]_ And when Rank comes, tell him

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: where he will find me. _[Nods to her, takes his papers and goes into

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: his room, and shuts the door after him.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[bewildered with anxiety, stands as if rooted to the spot, and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: whispers]_. He was capable of doing it. He will do it. He will do it in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: spite of everything.—No, not that! Never, never! Anything rather than

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: that! Oh, for some help, some way out of it! _[The door-bell rings.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Doctor Rank! Anything rather than that—anything, whatever it is! _[She

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: puts her hands over her face, pulls herself together, goes to the door

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and opens it. RANK is standing without, hanging up his coat. During the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: following dialogue it begins to grow dark.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Good day, Doctor Rank. I knew your ring. But you mustn’t go in to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald now; I think he is busy with something.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: And you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[brings him in and shuts the door after him]_. Oh, you know very well

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I always have time for you.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Thank you. I shall make use of as much of it as I can.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you mean by that? As much of it as you can?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, does that alarm you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It was such a strange way of putting it. Is anything likely to happen?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Nothing but what I have long been prepared for. But I certainly didn’t

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: expect it to happen so soon.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[gripping him by the arm]_. What have you found out? Doctor Rank, you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: must tell me.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[sitting down by the stove]_. It is all up with me. And it can’t be

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: helped.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[with a sigh of relief]_. Is it about yourself?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Who else? It is no use lying to one’s self. I am the most wretched of

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: all my patients, Mrs Helmer. Lately I have been taking stock of my

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: internal economy. Bankrupt! Probably within a month I shall lie rotting

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: in the churchyard.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What an ugly thing to say!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: The thing itself is cursedly ugly, and the worst of it is that I shall

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: have to face so much more that is ugly before that. I shall only make

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: one more examination of myself; when I have done that, I shall know

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: pretty certainly when it will be that the horrors of dissolution will

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: begin. There is something I want to tell you. Helmer’s refined nature

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: gives him an unconquerable disgust at everything that is ugly; I won’t

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: have him in my sick-room.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, but, Doctor Rank—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I won’t have him there. Not on any account. I bar my door to him. As

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: soon as I am quite certain that the worst has come, I shall send you my

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: card with a black cross on it, and then you will know that the

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: loathsome end has begun.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You are quite absurd today. And I wanted you so much to be in a really

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: good humour.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: With death stalking beside me?—To have to pay this penalty for another

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: man’s sin? Is there any justice in that? And in every single family, in

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: one way or another, some such inexorable retribution is being exacted—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting her hands over her ears]_. Rubbish! Do talk of something

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: cheerful.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Oh, it’s a mere laughing matter, the whole thing. My poor innocent

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: spine has to suffer for my father’s youthful amusements.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[sitting at the table on the left]_. I suppose you mean that he was

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: too partial to asparagus and pate de foie gras, don’t you?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, and to truffles.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Truffles, yes. And oysters too, I suppose?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Oysters, of course, that goes without saying.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And heaps of port and champagne. It is sad that all these nice things

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: should take their revenge on our bones.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Especially that they should revenge themselves on the unlucky bones of

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: those who have not had the satisfaction of enjoying them.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, that’s the saddest part of it all.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[with a searching look at her]_. Hm!—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[after a short pause]_. Why did you smile?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: No, it was you that laughed.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, it was you that smiled, Doctor Rank!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[rising]_. You are a greater rascal than I thought.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am in a silly mood today.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: So it seems.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting her hands on his shoulders]_. Dear, dear Doctor Rank, death

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: mustn’t take you away from Torvald and me.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: It is a loss you would easily recover from. Those who are gone are soon

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: forgotten.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looking at him anxiously]_. Do you believe that?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: People form new ties, and then—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Who will form new ties?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Both you and Helmer, when I am gone. You yourself are already on the

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: high road to it, I think. What did that Mrs Linde want here last night?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oho!—you don’t mean to say you are jealous of poor Christine?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, I am. She will be my successor in this house. When I am done for,

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: this woman will—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Hush! don’t speak so loud. She is in that room.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Today again. There, you see.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: She has only come to sew my dress for me. Bless my soul, how

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: unreasonable you are! _[Sits down on the sofa.]_ Be nice now, Doctor

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Rank, and tomorrow you will see how beautifully I shall dance, and you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: can imagine I am doing it all for you—and for Torvald too, of course.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Takes various things out of the box.]_ Doctor Rank, come and sit down

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: here, and I will show you something.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[sitting down]_. What is it?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Just look at those!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Silk stockings.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Flesh-coloured. Aren’t they lovely? It is so dark here now, but

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tomorrow—. No, no, no! you must only look at the feet. Oh well, you may

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: have leave to look at the legs too.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Hm!—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Why are you looking so critical? Don’t you think they will fit me?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I have no means of forming an opinion about that.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looks at him for a moment]_. For shame! _[Hits him lightly on the ear

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: with the stockings.]_ That’s to punish you. _[Folds them up again.]_

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: And what other nice things am I to be allowed to see?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Not a single thing more, for being so naughty. _[She looks among the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: things, humming to herself.]_

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[after a short silence]_. When I am sitting here, talking to you as

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: intimately as this, I cannot imagine for a moment what would have

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: become of me if I had never come into this house.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[smiling]_. I believe you do feel thoroughly at home with us.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[in a lower voice, looking straight in front of him]_. And to be

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: obliged to leave it all—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nonsense, you are not going to leave it.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[as before]_. And not be able to leave behind one the slightest token

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: of one’s gratitude, scarcely even a fleeting regret—nothing but an

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: empty place which the first comer can fill as well as any other.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And if I asked you now for a—? No!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: For what?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: For a big proof of your friendship—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, yes!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I mean a tremendously big favour—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Would you really make me so happy for once?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Ah, but you don’t know what it is yet.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: No—but tell me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I really can’t, Doctor Rank. It is something out of all reason; it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: means advice, and help, and a favour—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: The bigger a thing it is the better. I can’t conceive what it is you

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: mean. Do tell me. Haven’t I your confidence?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: More than anyone else. I know you are my truest and best friend, and so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I will tell you what it is. Well, Doctor Rank, it is something you must

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: help me to prevent. You know how devotedly, how inexpressibly deeply

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald loves me; he would never for a moment hesitate to give his life

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: for me.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[leaning towards her]_. Nora—do you think he is the only one—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[with a slight start]_. The only one—?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: The only one who would gladly give his life for your sake.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[sadly]_. Is that it?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I was determined you should know it before I went away, and there will

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: never be a better opportunity than this. Now you know it, Nora. And now

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: you know, too, that you can trust me as you would trust no one else.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[rises, deliberately and quietly]_. Let me pass.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[makes room for her to pass him, but sits still]_. Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[at the hall door]_. Helen, bring in the lamp. _[Goes over to the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: stove.]_ Dear Doctor Rank, that was really horrid of you.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: To have loved you as much as anyone else does? Was that horrid?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, but to go and tell me so. There was really no need—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: What do you mean? Did you know—? _[MAID enters with lamp, puts it down

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: on the table, and goes out.]_ Nora—Mrs Helmer—tell me, had you any idea

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: of this?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, how do I know whether I had or whether I hadn’t? I really can’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tell you—To think you could be so clumsy, Doctor Rank! We were getting

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: on so nicely.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, at all events you know now that you can command me, body and

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: soul. So won’t you speak out?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looking at him]_. After what happened?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I beg you to let me know what it is.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I can’t tell you anything now.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, yes. You mustn’t punish me in that way. Let me have permission to

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: do for you whatever a man may do.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You can do nothing for me now. Besides, I really don’t need any help at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: all. You will find that the whole thing is merely fancy on my part. It

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: really is so—of course it is! _[Sits down in the rocking-chair, and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: looks at him with a smile.]_ You are a nice sort of man, Doctor

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Rank!—don’t you feel ashamed of yourself, now the lamp has come?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Not a bit. But perhaps I had better go—for ever?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, indeed, you shall not. Of course you must come here just as before.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You know very well Torvald can’t do without you.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, but you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, I am always tremendously pleased when you come.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: It is just that, that put me on the wrong track. You are a riddle to

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: me. I have often thought that you would almost as soon be in my company

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: as in Helmer’s.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes—you see there are some people one loves best, and others whom one

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: would almost always rather have as companions.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, there is something in that.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: When I was at home, of course I loved papa best. But I always thought

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it tremendous fun if I could steal down into the maids’ room, because

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: they never moralised at all, and talked to each other about such

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: entertaining things.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I see—it is their place I have taken.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[jumping up and going to him]_. Oh, dear, nice Doctor Rank, I never

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: meant that at all. But surely you can understand that being with

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald is a little like being with papa—_[Enter MAID from the hall.]_

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: If you please, ma’am. _[Whispers and hands her a card.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[glancing at the card]_. Oh! _[Puts it in her pocket.]_

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Is there anything wrong?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no, not in the least. It is only something—it is my new dress—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: What? Your dress is lying there.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, yes, that one; but this is another. I ordered it. Torvald mustn’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: know about it—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Oho! Then that was the great secret.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Of course. Just go in to him; he is sitting in the inner room. Keep him

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: as long as—

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Make your mind easy; I won’t let him escape.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[Goes into HELMER’S room.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[to the MAID]_. And he is standing waiting in the kitchen?

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Yes; he came up the back stairs.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But didn’t you tell him no one was in?

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Yes, but it was no good.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He won’t go away?

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: No; he says he won’t until he has seen you, ma’am.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well, let him come in—but quietly. Helen, you mustn’t say anything

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: about it to anyone. It is a surprise for my husband.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Yes, ma’am, I quite understand. _[Exit.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: This dreadful thing is going to happen! It will happen in spite of me!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no, no, it can’t happen—it shan’t happen! _[She bolts the door of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: HELMER’S room. The MAID opens the hall door for KROGSTAD and shuts it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: after him. He is wearing a fur coat, high boots and a fur cap.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[advancing towards him]_. Speak low—my husband is at home.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: No matter about that.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you want of me?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: An explanation of something.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Make haste then. What is it?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: You know, I suppose, that I have got my dismissal.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I couldn’t prevent it, Mr. Krogstad. I fought as hard as I could on

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: your side, but it was no good.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Does your husband love you so little, then? He knows what I can expose

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you to, and yet he ventures—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How can you suppose that he has any knowledge of the sort?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I didn’t suppose so at all. It would not be the least like our dear

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Torvald Helmer to show so much courage—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Mr. Krogstad, a little respect for my husband, please.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Certainly—all the respect he deserves. But since you have kept the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: matter so carefully to yourself, I make bold to suppose that you have a

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: little clearer idea, than you had yesterday, of what it actually is

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: that you have done?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: More than you could ever teach me.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Yes, such a bad lawyer as I am.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What is it you want of me?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Only to see how you were, Mrs Helmer. I have been thinking about you

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: all day long. A mere cashier, a quill-driver, a—well, a man like

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: me—even he has a little of what is called feeling, you know.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Show it, then; think of my little children.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Have you and your husband thought of mine? But never mind about that. I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: only wanted to tell you that you need not take this matter too

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: seriously. In the first place there will be no accusation made on my

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: part.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, of course not; I was sure of that.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: The whole thing can be arranged amicably; there is no reason why anyone

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: should know anything about it. It will remain a secret between us

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: three.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: My husband must never get to know anything about it.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: How will you be able to prevent it? Am I to understand that you can pay

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: the balance that is owing?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, not just at present.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Or perhaps that you have some expedient for raising the money soon?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No expedient that I mean to make use of.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Well, in any case, it would have been of no use to you now. If you

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: stood there with ever so much money in your hand, I would never part

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: with your bond.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Tell me what purpose you mean to put it to.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I shall only preserve it—keep it in my possession. No one who is not

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: concerned in the matter shall have the slightest hint of it. So that if

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: the thought of it has driven you to any desperate resolution—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It has.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: If you had it in your mind to run away from your home—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I had.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Or even something worse—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How could you know that?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Give up the idea.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How did you know I had thought of that?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Most of us think of that at first. I did, too—but I hadn’t the courage.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[faintly]_. No more had I.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[in a tone of relief]_. No, that’s it, isn’t it—you hadn’t the courage

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: either?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I haven’t—I haven’t.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Besides, it would have been a great piece of folly. Once the first

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: storm at home is over—. I have a letter for your husband in my pocket.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Telling him everything?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: In as lenient a manner as I possibly could.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[quickly]_. He mustn’t get the letter. Tear it up. I will find some

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: means of getting money.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Excuse me, Mrs Helmer, but I think I told you just now—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am not speaking of what I owe you. Tell me what sum you are asking my

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband for, and I will get the money.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I am not asking your husband for a penny.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you want, then?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I will tell you. I want to rehabilitate myself, Mrs Helmer; I want to

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: get on; and in that your husband must help me. For the last year and a

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: half I have not had a hand in anything dishonourable, amid all that

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: time I have been struggling in most restricted circumstances. I was

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: content to work my way up step by step. Now I am turned out, and I am

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: not going to be satisfied with merely being taken into favour again. I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: want to get on, I tell you. I want to get into the Bank again, in a

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: higher position. Your husband must make a place for me—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That he will never do!

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: He will; I know him; he dare not protest. And as soon as I am in there

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: again with him, then you will see! Within a year I shall be the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: manager’s right hand. It will be Nils Krogstad and not Torvald Helmer

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: who manages the Bank.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That’s a thing you will never see!

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Do you mean that you will—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I have courage enough for it now.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Oh, you can’t frighten me. A fine, spoilt lady like you—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You will see, you will see.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Under the ice, perhaps? Down into the cold, coal-black water? And then,

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: in the spring, to float up to the surface, all horrible and

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: unrecognisable, with your hair fallen out—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You can’t frighten me.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Nor you me. People don’t do such things, Mrs Helmer. Besides, what use

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: would it be? I should have him completely in my power all the same.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Afterwards? When I am no longer—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Have you forgotten that it is I who have the keeping of your

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: reputation? _[NORA stands speechlessly looking at him.]_ Well, now, I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: have warned you. Do not do anything foolish. When Helmer has had my

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: letter, I shall expect a message from him. And be sure you remember

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: that it is your husband himself who has forced me into such ways as

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: this again. I will never forgive him for that. Goodbye, Mrs Helmer.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[Exit through the hall.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[goes to the hall door, opens it slightly and listens.]_ He is going.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He is not putting the letter in the box. Oh no, no! that’s impossible!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Opens the door by degrees.]_ What is that? He is standing outside. He

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is not going downstairs. Is he hesitating? Can he—? _[A letter drops

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: into the box; then KROGSTAD’S footsteps are heard, until they die away

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: as he goes downstairs. NORA utters a stifled cry, and runs across the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: room to the table by the sofa. A short pause.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: In the letter-box. _[Steals across to the hall door.]_ There it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: lies—Torvald, Torvald, there is no hope for us now!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Mrs Linde comes in from the room on the left, carrying the dress.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: There, I can’t see anything more to mend now. Would you like to try it

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: on—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[in a hoarse whisper]_. Christine, come here.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[throwing the dress down on the sofa]_. What is the matter with you?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You look so agitated!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Come here. Do you see that letter? There, look—you can see it through

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the glass in the letter-box.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, I see it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That letter is from Krogstad.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora—it was Krogstad who lent you the money!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, and now Torvald will know all about it.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Believe me, Nora, that’s the best thing for both of you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You don’t know all. I forged a name.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Good heavens—!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I only want to say this to you, Christine—you must be my witness.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Your witness? What do you mean? What am I to—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If I should go out of my mind—and it might easily happen—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Or if anything else should happen to me—anything, for instance, that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: might prevent my being here—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora! Nora! you are quite out of your mind.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And if it should happen that there were some one who wanted to take all

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the responsibility, all the blame, you understand—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, yes—but how can you suppose—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Then you must be my witness, that it is not true, Christine. I am not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: out of my mind at all; I am in my right senses now, and I tell you no

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: one else has known anything about it; I, and I alone, did the whole

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: thing. Remember that.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I will, indeed. But I don’t understand all this.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How should you understand it? A wonderful thing is going to happen!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: A wonderful thing?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, a wonderful thing!—But it is so terrible, Christine; it mustn’t

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: happen, not for all the world.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I will go at once and see Krogstad.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Don’t go to him; he will do you some harm.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: There was a time when he would gladly do anything for my sake.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: He?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Where does he live?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How should I know—? Yes _[feeling in her pocket]_, here is his card.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But the letter, the letter—!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[calls from his room, knocking at the door]_. Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[cries out anxiously]_. Oh, what’s that? What do you want?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Don’t be so frightened. We are not coming in; you have locked the door.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Are you trying on your dress?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, that’s it. I look so nice, Torvald.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[who has read the card]_. I see he lives at the corner here.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, but it’s no use. It is hopeless. The letter is lying there in the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: box.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: And your husband keeps the key?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, always.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Krogstad must ask for his letter back unread, he must find some

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: pretence—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: But it is just at this time that Torvald generally—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You must delay him. Go in to him in the meantime. I will come back as

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: soon as I can. _[She goes out hurriedly through the hall door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[goes to HELMER’S door, opens it and peeps in]_. Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[from the inner room]_. Well? May I venture at last to come into my

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: own room again? Come along, Rank, now you will see— _[Halting in the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: doorway.]_ But what is this?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What is what, dear?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Rank led me to expect a splendid transformation.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[in the doorway]_. I understood so, but evidently I was mistaken.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, nobody is to have the chance of admiring me in my dress until

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tomorrow.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But, my dear Nora, you look so worn out. Have you been practising too

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: much?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I have not practised at all.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But you will need to—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, indeed I shall, Torvald. But I can’t get on a bit without you to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: help me; I have absolutely forgotten the whole thing.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Oh, we will soon work it up again.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, help me, Torvald. Promise that you will! I am so nervous about

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it—all the people—. You must give yourself up to me entirely this

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: evening. Not the tiniest bit of business—you mustn’t even take a pen in

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: your hand. Will you promise, Torvald dear?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I promise. This evening I will be wholly and absolutely at your

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: service, you helpless little mortal. Ah, by the way, first of all I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: will just— _[Goes towards the hall door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What are you going to do there?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Only see if any letters have come.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, no! don’t do that, Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Why not?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald, please don’t. There is nothing there.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well, let me look. _[Turns to go to the letter-box. NORA, at the piano,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: plays the first bars of the Tarantella. HELMER stops in the doorway.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Aha!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I can’t dance tomorrow if I don’t practise with you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[going up to her]_. Are you really so afraid of it, dear?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, so dreadfully afraid of it. Let me practise at once; there is time

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now, before we go to dinner. Sit down and play for me, Torvald dear;

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: criticise me, and correct me as you play.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: With great pleasure, if you wish me to. _[Sits down at the piano.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[takes out of the box a tambourine and a long variegated shawl. She

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hastily drapes the shawl round her. Then she springs to the front of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the stage and calls out]_. Now play for me! I am going to dance!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[HELMER plays and NORA dances. RANK stands by the piano behind HELMER,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and looks on.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[as he plays]_. Slower, slower!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I can’t do it any other way.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not so violently, Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: This is the way.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[stops playing]_. No, no—that is not a bit right.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[laughing and swinging the tambourine]_. Didn’t I tell you so?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Let me play for her.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[getting up]_. Yes, do. I can correct her better then.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[RANK sits down at the piano and plays. NORA dances more and more

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: wildly. HELMER has taken up a position beside the stove, and during her

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: dance gives her frequent instructions. She does not seem to hear him;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: her hair comes down and falls over her shoulders; she pays no attention

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: to it, but goes on dancing. Enter Mrs Linde.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[standing as if spell-bound in the doorway]_. Oh!—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[as she dances]_. Such fun, Christine!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My dear darling Nora, you are dancing as if your life depended on it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: So it does.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Stop, Rank; this is sheer madness. Stop, I tell you! _[RANK stops

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: playing, and NORA suddenly stands still. HELMER goes up to her.]_ I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: could never have believed it. You have forgotten everything I taught

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[throwing away the tambourine]_. There, you see.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You will want a lot of coaching.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, you see how much I need it. You must coach me up to the last

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: minute. Promise me that, Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You can depend on me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You must not think of anything but me, either today or tomorrow; you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: mustn’t open a single letter—not even open the letter-box—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Ah, you are still afraid of that fellow—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, indeed I am.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, I can tell from your looks that there is a letter from him lying

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: there.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I don’t know; I think there is; but you must not read anything of that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: kind now. Nothing horrid must come between us until this is all over.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[whispers to HELMER]_. You mustn’t contradict her.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[taking her in his arms]_. The child shall have her way. But tomorrow

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: night, after you have danced—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Then you will be free. _[The MAID appears in the doorway to the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: right.]_

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Dinner is served, ma’am.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: We will have champagne, Helen.

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: Very good, ma’am. _[Exit.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Hullo!—are we going to have a banquet?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, a champagne banquet until the small hours. _[Calls out.]_ And a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: few macaroons, Helen—lots, just for once!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Come, come, don’t be so wild and nervous. Be my own little skylark, as

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you used.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, dear, I will. But go in now and you too, Doctor Rank. Christine,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: you must help me to do up my hair.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[whispers to HELMER as they go out]_. I suppose there is nothing—she

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: is not expecting anything?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Far from it, my dear fellow; it is simply nothing more than this

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: childish nervousness I was telling you of. _[They go into the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: right-hand room.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Well!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Gone out of town.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I could tell from your face.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: He is coming home tomorrow evening. I wrote a note for him.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You should have let it alone; you must prevent nothing. After all, it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is splendid to be waiting for a wonderful thing to happen.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: What is it that you are waiting for?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Oh, you wouldn’t understand. Go in to them, I will come in a moment.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Mrs Linde goes into the dining-room. NORA stands still for a little

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: while, as if to compose herself. Then she looks at her watch.]_ Five

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: o’clock. Seven hours until midnight; and then four-and-twenty hours

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: until the next midnight. Then the Tarantella will be over. Twenty-four

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and seven? Thirty-one hours to live.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[from the doorway on the right]_. Where’s my little skylark?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going to him with her arms outstretched]_. Here she is!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: ACT III

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[THE SAME SCENE.—The table has been placed in the middle of the stage,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: with chairs around it. A lamp is burning on the table. The door into

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the hall stands open. Dance music is heard in the room above. Mrs Linde

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is sitting at the table idly turning over the leaves of a book; she

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: tries to read, but does not seem able to collect her thoughts. Every

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now and then she listens intently for a sound at the outer door.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[looking at her watch]_. Not yet—and the time is nearly up. If only he

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: does not—. _[Listens again.]_ Ah, there he is. _[Goes into the hall and

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: opens the outer door carefully. Light footsteps are heard on the

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: stairs. She whispers.]_ Come in. There is no one here.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[in the doorway]_. I found a note from you at home. What does this

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: mean?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: It is absolutely necessary that I should have a talk with you.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Really? And is it absolutely necessary that it should be here?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: It is impossible where I live; there is no private entrance to my

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: rooms. Come in; we are quite alone. The maid is asleep, and the Helmers

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: are at the dance upstairs.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[coming into the room]_. Are the Helmers really at a dance tonight?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, why not?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Certainly—why not?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Now, Nils, let us have a talk.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Can we two have anything to talk about?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: We have a great deal to talk about.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I shouldn’t have thought so.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, you have never properly understood me.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Was there anything else to understand except what was obvious to all

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: the world—a heartless woman jilts a man when a more lucrative chance

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: turns up?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Do you believe I am as absolutely heartless as all that? And do you

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: believe that I did it with a light heart?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Didn’t you?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nils, did you really think that?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: If it were as you say, why did you write to me as you did at the time?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I could do nothing else. As I had to break with you, it was my duty

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: also to put an end to all that you felt for me.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[wringing his hands]_. So that was it. And all this—only for the sake

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: of money!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You must not forget that I had a helpless mother and two little

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: brothers. We couldn’t wait for you, Nils; your prospects seemed

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: hopeless then.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: That may be so, but you had no right to throw me over for anyone else’s

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: sake.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Indeed I don’t know. Many a time did I ask myself if I had the right to

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: do it.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[more gently]_. When I lost you, it was as if all the solid ground

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: went from under my feet. Look at me now—I am a shipwrecked man clinging

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: to a bit of wreckage.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But help may be near.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: It was near; but then you came and stood in my way.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Unintentionally, Nils. It was only today that I learned it was your

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: place I was going to take in the Bank.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I believe you, if you say so. But now that you know it, are you not

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: going to give it up to me?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, because that would not benefit you in the least.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Oh, benefit, benefit—I would have done it whether or no.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I have learned to act prudently. Life, and hard, bitter necessity have

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: taught me that.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: And life has taught me not to believe in fine speeches.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Then life has taught you something very reasonable. But deeds you must

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: believe in?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: What do you mean by that?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You said you were like a shipwrecked man clinging to some wreckage.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I had good reason to say so.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Well, I am like a shipwrecked woman clinging to some wreckage—no one to

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: mourn for, no one to care for.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: It was your own choice.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: There was no other choice—then.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Well, what now?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nils, how would it be if we two shipwrecked people could join forces?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: What are you saying?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Two on the same piece of wreckage would stand a better chance than each

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: on their own.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Christine I...

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: What do you suppose brought me to town?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Do you mean that you gave me a thought?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I could not endure life without work. All my life, as long as I can

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: remember, I have worked, and it has been my greatest and only pleasure.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: But now I am quite alone in the world—my life is so dreadfully empty

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: and I feel so forsaken. There is not the least pleasure in working for

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: one’s self. Nils, give me someone and something to work for.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I don’t trust that. It is nothing but a woman’s overstrained sense of

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: generosity that prompts you to make such an offer of yourself.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Have you ever noticed anything of the sort in me?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Could you really do it? Tell me—do you know all about my past life?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: And do you know what they think of me here?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You seemed to me to imply that with me you might have been quite

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: another man.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I am certain of it.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Is it too late now?

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Christine, are you saying this deliberately? Yes, I am sure you are. I

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: see it in your face. Have you really the courage, then—?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I want to be a mother to someone, and your children need a mother. We

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: two need each other. Nils, I have faith in your real character—I can

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: dare anything together with you.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[grasps her hands]_. Thanks, thanks, Christine! Now I shall find a way

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: to clear myself in the eyes of the world. Ah, but I forgot—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[listening]_. Hush! The Tarantella! Go, go!

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Why? What is it?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Do you hear them up there? When that is over, we may expect them back.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Yes, yes—I will go. But it is all no use. Of course you are not aware

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: what steps I have taken in the matter of the Helmers.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, I know all about that.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: And in spite of that have you the courage to—?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I understand very well to what lengths a man like you might be driven

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: by despair.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: If I could only undo what I have done!

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You cannot. Your letter is lying in the letter-box now.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Are you sure of that?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Quite sure, but—

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[with a searching look at her]_. Is that what it all means?—that you

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: want to save your friend at any cost? Tell me frankly. Is that it?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nils, a woman who has once sold herself for another’s sake, doesn’t do

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: it a second time.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I will ask for my letter back.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, no.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Yes, of course I will. I will wait here until Helmer comes; I will tell

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: him he must give me my letter back—that it only concerns my

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: dismissal—that he is not to read it—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: No, Nils, you must not recall your letter.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: But, tell me, wasn’t it for that very purpose that you asked me to meet

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: you here?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: In my first moment of fright, it was. But twenty-four hours have

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: elapsed since then, and in that time I have witnessed incredible things

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: in this house. Helmer must know all about it. This unhappy secret must

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: be disclosed; they must have a complete understanding between them,

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: which is impossible with all this concealment and falsehood going on.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: Very well, if you will take the responsibility. But there is one thing

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I can do in any case, and I shall do it at once.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[listening]_. You must be quick and go! The dance is over; we are not

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: safe a moment longer.

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I will wait for you below.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, do. You must see me back to my door...

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: I have never had such an amazing piece of good fortune in my life!

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: _[Goes out through the outer door. The door between the room and the

SPEAKER: KROGSTAD
TEXT: hall remains open.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[tidying up the room and laying her hat and cloak ready]_. What a

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: difference! what a difference! Someone to work for and live for—a home

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: to bring comfort into. That I will do, indeed. I wish they would be

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: quick and come—_[Listens.]_ Ah, there they are now. I must put on my

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: things. _[Takes up her hat and cloak. HELMER’S and NORA’S voices are

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: heard outside; a key is turned, and HELMER brings NORA almost by force

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: into the hall. She is in an Italian costume with a large black shawl

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: around her; he is in evening dress, and a black domino which is flying

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: open.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[hanging back in the doorway, and struggling with him]_. No, no,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: no!—don’t take me in. I want to go upstairs again; I don’t want to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: leave so early.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But, my dearest Nora—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Please, Torvald dear—please, please—only an hour more.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not a single minute, my sweet Nora. You know that was our agreement.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Come along into the room; you are catching cold standing there. _[He

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: brings her gently into the room, in spite of her resistance.]_

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Good evening.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Christine!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You here, so late, Mrs Linde?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, you must excuse me; I was so anxious to see Nora in her dress.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Have you been sitting here waiting for me?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, unfortunately I came too late, you had already gone upstairs; and

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: I thought I couldn’t go away again without having seen you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[taking off NORA’S shawl]_. Yes, take a good look at her. I think she

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: is worth looking at. Isn’t she charming, Mrs Linde?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, indeed she is.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Doesn’t she look remarkably pretty? Everyone thought so at the dance.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But she is terribly self-willed, this sweet little person. What are we

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: to do with her? You will hardly believe that I had almost to bring her

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: away by force.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald, you will repent not having let me stay, even if it were only

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: for half an hour.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Listen to her, Mrs Linde! She had danced her Tarantella, and it had

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: been a tremendous success, as it deserved—although possibly the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: performance was a trifle too realistic—a little more so, I mean, than

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: was strictly compatible with the limitations of art. But never mind

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: about that! The chief thing is, she had made a success—she had made a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: tremendous success. Do you think I was going to let her remain there

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: after that, and spoil the effect? No, indeed! I took my charming little

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Capri maiden—my capricious little Capri maiden, I should say—on my arm;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: took one quick turn round the room; a curtsey on either side, and, as

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: they say in novels, the beautiful apparition disappeared. An exit ought

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: always to be effective, Mrs Linde; but that is what I cannot make Nora

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: understand. Pooh! this room is hot. _[Throws his domino on a chair, and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: opens the door of his room.]_ Hullo! it’s all dark in here. Oh, of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: course—excuse me—. _[He goes in, and lights some candles.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[in a hurried and breathless whisper]_. Well?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[in a low voice]_. I have had a talk with him.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, and—

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Nora, you must tell your husband all about it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[in an expressionless voice]_. I knew it.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: You have nothing to be afraid of as far as Krogstad is concerned; but

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: you must tell him.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I won’t tell him.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Then the letter will.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Thank you, Christine. Now I know what I must do. Hush—!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[coming in again]_. Well, Mrs Linde, have you admired her?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, and now I will say goodnight.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What, already? Is this yours, this knitting?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: _[taking it]_. Yes, thank you, I had very nearly forgotten it.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: So you knit?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Of course.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Do you know, you ought to embroider.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Really? Why?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, it’s far more becoming. Let me show you. You hold the embroidery

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: thus in your left hand, and use the needle with the right—like

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: this—with a long, easy sweep. Do you see?

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Yes, perhaps—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But in the case of knitting—that can never be anything but ungraceful;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: look here—the arms close together, the knitting-needles going up and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: down—it has a sort of Chinese effect—. That was really excellent

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: champagne they gave us.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Well,—goodnight, Nora, and don’t be self-willed any more.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That’s right, Mrs Linde.

SPEAKER: MRS LINDE
TEXT: Goodnight, Mr. Helmer.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[accompanying her to the door]_. Goodnight, goodnight. I hope you will

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: get home all right. I should be very happy to—but you haven’t any great

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: distance to go. Goodnight, goodnight. _[She goes out; he shuts the door

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: after her, and comes in again.]_ Ah!—at last we have got rid of her.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: She is a frightful bore, that woman.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Aren’t you very tired, Torvald?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No, not in the least.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Nor sleepy?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not a bit. On the contrary, I feel extraordinarily lively. And you?—you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: really look both tired and sleepy.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I am very tired. I want to go to sleep at once.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There, you see it was quite right of me not to let you stay there any

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: longer.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Everything you do is quite right, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[kissing her on the forehead]_. Now my little skylark is speaking

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: reasonably. Did you notice what good spirits Rank was in this evening?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Really? Was he? I didn’t speak to him at all.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And I very little, but I have not for a long time seen him in such good

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: form. _[Looks for a while at her and then goes nearer to her.]_ It is

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: delightful to be at home by ourselves again, to be all alone with

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you—you fascinating, charming little darling!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Don’t look at me like that, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Why shouldn’t I look at my dearest treasure?—at all the beauty that is

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: mine, all my very own?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going to the other side of the table]_. You mustn’t say things like

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: that to me tonight.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[following her]_. You have still got the Tarantella in your blood, I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: see. And it makes you more captivating than ever. Listen—the guests are

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: beginning to go now. _[In a lower voice.]_ Nora—soon the whole house

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: will be quiet.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I hope so.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, my own darling Nora. Do you know, when I am out at a party with

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you like this, why I speak so little to you, keep away from you, and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: only send a stolen glance in your direction now and then?—do you know

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: why I do that? It is because I make believe to myself that we are

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: secretly in love, and you are my secretly promised bride, and that no

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: one suspects there is anything between us.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, yes—I know very well your thoughts are with me all the time.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And when we are leaving, and I am putting the shawl over your beautiful

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: young shoulders—on your lovely neck—then I imagine that you are my

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: young bride and that we have just come from the wedding, and I am

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: bringing you for the first time into our home—to be alone with you for

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: the first time—quite alone with my shy little darling! All this evening

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I have longed for nothing but you. When I watched the seductive figures

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: of the Tarantella, my blood was on fire; I could endure it no longer,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and that was why I brought you down so early—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Go away, Torvald! You must let me go. I won’t—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What’s that? You’re joking, my little Nora! You won’t—you won’t? Am I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: not your husband—? _[A knock is heard at the outer door.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[starting]_. Did you hear—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[going into the hall]_. Who is it?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[outside]_. It is I. May I come in for a moment?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[in a fretful whisper]_. Oh, what does he want now? _[Aloud.]_ Wait a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: minute! _[Unlocks the door.]_ Come, that’s kind of you not to pass by

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: our door.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: I thought I heard your voice, and felt as if I should like to look in.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[With a swift glance round.]_ Ah, yes!—these dear familiar rooms. You

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: are very happy and cosy in here, you two.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It seems to me that you looked after yourself pretty well upstairs too.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Excellently. Why shouldn’t I? Why shouldn’t one enjoy everything in

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: this world?—at any rate as much as one can, and as long as one can. The

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: wine was capital—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Especially the champagne.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: So you noticed that too? It is almost incredible how much I managed to

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: put away!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald drank a great deal of champagne tonight too.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Did he?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, and he is always in such good spirits afterwards.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Well, why should one not enjoy a merry evening after a well-spent day?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well spent? I am afraid I can’t take credit for that.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[clapping him on the back]_. But I can, you know!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Doctor Rank, you must have been occupied with some scientific

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: investigation today.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Exactly.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Just listen!—little Nora talking about scientific investigations!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And may I congratulate you on the result?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Indeed you may.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Was it favourable, then?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: The best possible, for both doctor and patient—certainty.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[quickly and searchingly]_. Certainty?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Absolute certainty. So wasn’t I entitled to make a merry evening of it

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: after that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, you certainly were, Doctor Rank.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I think so too, so long as you don’t have to pay for it in the morning.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Oh well, one can’t have anything in this life without paying for it.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Doctor Rank—are you fond of fancy-dress balls?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, if there is a fine lot of pretty costumes.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Tell me—what shall we two wear at the next?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Little featherbrain!—are you thinking of the next already?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: We two? Yes, I can tell you. You shall go as a good fairy—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, but what do you suggest as an appropriate costume for that?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Let your wife go dressed just as she is in everyday life.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That was really very prettily turned. But can’t you tell us what you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: will be?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Yes, my dear friend, I have quite made up my mind about that.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: At the next fancy-dress ball I shall be invisible.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That’s a good joke!

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: There is a big black hat—have you never heard of hats that make you

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: invisible? If you put one on, no one can see you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[suppressing a smile]_. Yes, you are quite right.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: But I am clean forgetting what I came for. Helmer, give me a cigar—one

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: of the dark Havanas.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: With the greatest pleasure. _[Offers him his case.]_

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: _[takes a cigar and cuts off the end]_. Thanks.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[striking a match]_. Let me give you a light.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Thank you. _[She holds the match for him to light his cigar.]_ And now

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: goodbye!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Goodbye, goodbye, dear old man!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Sleep well, Doctor Rank.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: Thank you for that wish.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Wish me the same.

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: You? Well, if you want me to sleep well! And thanks for the light. _[He

SPEAKER: RANK
TEXT: nods to them both and goes out.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[in a subdued voice]_. He has drunk more than he ought.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[absently]_. Maybe. _[HELMER takes a bunch of keys out of his pocket

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and goes into the hall.]_ Torvald! what are you going to do there?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Emptying the letter-box; it is quite full; there will be no room to put

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: the newspaper in tomorrow morning.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Are you going to work tonight?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You know quite well I’m not. What is this? Someone has been at the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: lock.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: At the lock—?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, someone has. What can it mean? I should never have thought the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: maid—. Here is a broken hairpin. Nora, it is one of yours.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[quickly]_. Then it must have been the children—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Then you must get them out of those ways. There, at last I have got it

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: open. _[Takes out the contents of the letter-box, and calls to the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: kitchen.]_ Helen!—Helen, put out the light over the front door. _[Goes

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: back into the room and shuts the door into the hall. He holds out his

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: hand full of letters.]_ Look at that—look what a heap of them there

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: are. _[Turning them over.]_ What on earth is that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[at the window]_. The letter—No! Torvald, no!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Two cards—of Rank’s.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Of Doctor Rank’s?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[looking at them]_. Doctor Rank. They were on the top. He must have

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: put them in when he went out.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Is there anything written on them?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There is a black cross over the name. Look there—what an uncomfortable

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: idea! It looks as if he were announcing his own death.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is just what he is doing.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What? Do you know anything about it? Has he said anything to you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes. He told me that when the cards came it would be his leave-taking

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: from us. He means to shut himself up and die.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: My poor old friend! Certainly I knew we should not have him very long

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: with us. But so soon! And so he hides himself away like a wounded

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: animal.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: If it has to happen, it is best it should be without a word—don’t you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: think so, Torvald?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[walking up and down]_. He had so grown into our lives. I can’t think

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: of him as having gone out of them. He, with his sufferings and his

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: loneliness, was like a cloudy background to our sunlit happiness. Well,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: perhaps it is best so. For him, anyway. _[Standing still.]_ And perhaps

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: for us too, Nora. We two are thrown quite upon each other now. _[Puts

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: his arms round her.]_ My darling wife, I don’t feel as if I could hold

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you tight enough. Do you know, Nora, I have often wished that you might

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: be threatened by some great danger, so that I might risk my life’s

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: blood, and everything, for your sake.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[disengages herself, and says firmly and decidedly]_. Now you must

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: read your letters, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No, no; not tonight. I want to be with you, my darling wife.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: With the thought of your friend’s death—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You are right, it has affected us both. Something ugly has come between

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: us—the thought of the horrors of death. We must try and rid our minds

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: of that. Until then—we will each go to our own room.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[hanging on his neck]_. Goodnight, Torvald—Goodnight!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[kissing her on the forehead]_. Goodnight, my little singing-bird.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Sleep sound, Nora. Now I will read my letters through. _[He takes his

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: letters and goes into his room, shutting the door after him.]_

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[gropes distractedly about, seizes HELMER’S domino, throws it round

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: her, while she says in quick, hoarse, spasmodic whispers]_. Never to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: see him again. Never! Never! _[Puts her shawl over her head.]_ Never to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: see my children again either—never again. Never! Never!—Ah! the icy,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: black water—the unfathomable depths—If only it were over! He has got it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: now—now he is reading it. Goodbye, Torvald and my children! _[She is

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: about to rush out through the hall, when HELMER opens his door

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: hurriedly and stands with an open letter in his hand.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Ah!—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What is this? Do you know what is in this letter?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, I know. Let me go! Let me get out!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[holding her back]_. Where are you going?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[trying to get free]_. You shan’t save me, Torvald!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[reeling]_. True? Is this true, that I read here? Horrible! No, no—it

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: is impossible that it can be true.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is true. I have loved you above everything else in the world.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Oh, don’t let us have any silly excuses.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[taking a step towards him]_. Torvald—!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Miserable creature—what have you done?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Let me go. You shall not suffer for my sake. You shall not take it upon

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: yourself.

SPEAKER: HELMER
