TEXT: No tragic airs, please. _[Locks the hall door.]_ Here you shall stay

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and give me an explanation. Do you understand what you have done?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Answer me! Do you understand what you have done?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looks steadily at him and says with a growing look of coldness in her

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: face]_. Yes, now I am beginning to understand thoroughly.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[walking about the room]_. What a horrible awakening! All these eight

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: years—she who was my joy and pride—a hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: criminal! The unutterable ugliness of it all!—For shame! For shame!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[NORA is silent and looks steadily at him. He stops in front of her.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I ought to have suspected that something of the sort would happen. I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: ought to have foreseen it. All your father’s want of principle—be

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: silent!—all your father’s want of principle has come out in you. No

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: religion, no morality, no sense of duty—. How I am punished for having

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: winked at what he did! I did it for your sake, and this is how you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: repay me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, that’s just it.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Now you have destroyed all my happiness. You have ruined all my future.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It is horrible to think of! I am in the power of an unscrupulous man;

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: he can do what he likes with me, ask anything he likes of me, give me

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: any orders he pleases—I dare not refuse. And I must sink to such

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: miserable depths because of a thoughtless woman!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: When I am out of the way, you will be free.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No fine speeches, please. Your father had always plenty of those ready,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: too. What good would it be to me if you were out of the way, as you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: say? Not the slightest. He can make the affair known everywhere; and if

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: he does, I may be falsely suspected of having been a party to your

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: criminal action. Very likely people will think I was behind it all—that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: it was I who prompted you! And I have to thank you for all this—you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: whom I have cherished during the whole of our married life. Do you

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: understand now what it is you have done for me?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[coldly and quietly]_. Yes.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It is so incredible that I can’t take it in. But we must come to some

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: understanding. Take off that shawl. Take it off, I tell you. I must try

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and appease him some way or another. The matter must be hushed up at

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: any cost. And as for you and me, it must appear as if everything

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: between us were just as before—but naturally only in the eyes of the

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: world. You will still remain in my house, that is a matter of course.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But I shall not allow you to bring up the children; I dare not trust

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: them to you. To think that I should be obliged to say so to one whom I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: have loved so dearly, and whom I still—. No, that is all over. From

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: this moment happiness is not the question; all that concerns us is to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: save the remains, the fragments, the appearance—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[A ring is heard at the front-door bell.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[with a start]_. What is that? So late! Can the worst—? Can he—? Hide

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: yourself, Nora. Say you are ill.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[NORA stands motionless. HELMER goes and unlocks the hall door.]_

SPEAKER: MAID
TEXT: _[half-dressed, comes to the door]_. A letter for the mistress.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Give it to me. _[Takes the letter, and shuts the door.]_ Yes, it is

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: from him. You shall not have it; I will read it myself.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, read it.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[standing by the lamp]_. I scarcely have the courage to do it. It may

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: mean ruin for both of us. No, I must know. _[Tears open the letter,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: runs his eye over a few lines, looks at a paper enclosed, and gives a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: shout of joy.]_ Nora! _[She looks at him questioningly.]_ Nora!—No, I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: must read it once again—. Yes, it is true! I am saved! Nora, I am

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: saved!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And I?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You too, of course; we are both saved, both you and I. Look, he sends

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you your bond back. He says he regrets and repents—that a happy change

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: in his life—never mind what he says! We are saved, Nora! No one can do

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: anything to you. Oh, Nora, Nora!—no, first I must destroy these hateful

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: things. Let me see—. _[Takes a look at the bond.]_ No, no, I won’t look

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: at it. The whole thing shall be nothing but a bad dream to me. _[Tears

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: up the bond and both letters, throws them all into the stove, and

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: watches them burn.]_ There—now it doesn’t exist any longer. He says

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: that since Christmas Eve you—. These must have been three dreadful days

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: for you, Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I have fought a hard fight these three days.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And suffered agonies, and seen no way out but—. No, we won’t call any

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: of the horrors to mind. We will only shout with joy, and keep saying,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: “It’s all over! It’s all over!” Listen to me, Nora. You don’t seem to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: realise that it is all over. What is this?—such a cold, set face! My

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: poor little Nora, I quite understand; you don’t feel as if you could

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: believe that I have forgiven you. But it is true, Nora, I swear it; I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: have forgiven you everything. I know that what you did, you did out of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: love for me.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That is true.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You have loved me as a wife ought to love her husband. Only you had not

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: sufficient knowledge to judge of the means you used. But do you suppose

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you are any the less dear to me, because you don’t understand how to

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: act on your own responsibility? No, no; only lean on me; I will advise

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you and direct you. I should not be a man if this womanly helplessness

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: did not just give you a double attractiveness in my eyes. You must not

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: think anymore about the hard things I said in my first moment of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: consternation, when I thought everything was going to overwhelm me. I

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: have forgiven you, Nora; I swear to you I have forgiven you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Thank you for your forgiveness. _[She goes out through the door to the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: right.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: No, don’t go—. _[Looks in.]_ What are you doing in there?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[from within]_. Taking off my fancy dress.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[standing at the open door]_. Yes, do. Try and calm yourself, and make

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: your mind easy again, my frightened little singing-bird. Be at rest,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and feel secure; I have broad wings to shelter you under. _[Walks up

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and down by the door.]_ How warm and cosy our home is, Nora. Here is

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: shelter for you; here I will protect you like a hunted dove that I have

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: saved from a hawk’s claws; I will bring peace to your poor beating

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: heart. It will come, little by little, Nora, believe me. Tomorrow

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: morning you will look upon it all quite differently; soon everything

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: will be just as it was before. Very soon you won’t need me to assure

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you that I have forgiven you; you will yourself feel the certainty that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I have done so. Can you suppose I should ever think of such a thing as

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: repudiating you, or even reproaching you? You have no idea what a true

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: man’s heart is like, Nora. There is something so indescribably sweet

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and satisfying, to a man, in the knowledge that he has forgiven his

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: wife—forgiven her freely, and with all his heart. It seems as if that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: had made her, as it were, doubly his own; he has given her a new life,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: so to speak; and she has in a way become both wife and child to him. So

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you shall be for me after this, my little scared, helpless darling.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Have no anxiety about anything, Nora; only be frank and open with me,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and I will serve as will and conscience both to you—. What is this? Not

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: gone to bed? Have you changed your things?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[in everyday dress]_. Yes, Torvald, I have changed my things now.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But what for?—so late as this.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I shall not sleep tonight.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But, my dear Nora—

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[looking at her watch]_. It is not so very late. Sit down here,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald. You and I have much to say to one another. _[She sits down at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: one side of the table.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora—what is this?—this cold, set face?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Sit down. It will take some time; I have a lot to talk over with you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[sits down at the opposite side of the table]_. You alarm me,

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora!—and I don’t understand you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, that is just it. You don’t understand me, and I have never

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: understood you either—before tonight. No, you mustn’t interrupt me. You

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: must simply listen to what I say. Torvald, this is a settling of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: accounts.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What do you mean by that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[after a short silence]_. Isn’t there one thing that strikes you as

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: strange in our sitting here like this?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What is that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: We have been married now eight years. Does it not occur to you that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: this is the first time we two, you and I, husband and wife, have had a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: serious conversation?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What do you mean by serious?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: In all these eight years—longer than that—from the very beginning of

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: our acquaintance, we have never exchanged a word on any serious

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: subject.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Was it likely that I would be continually and forever telling you about

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: worries that you could not help me to bear?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am not speaking about business matters. I say that we have never sat

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: down in earnest together to try and get at the bottom of anything.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But, dearest Nora, would it have been any good to you?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That is just it; you have never understood me. I have been greatly

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: wronged, Torvald—first by papa and then by you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What! By us two—by us two, who have loved you better than anyone else

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: in the world?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[shaking her head]_. You have never loved me. You have only thought it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: pleasant to be in love with me.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, what do I hear you saying?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is perfectly true, Torvald. When I was at home with papa, he told me

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: his opinion about everything, and so I had the same opinions; and if I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: differed from him I concealed the fact, because he would not have liked

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it. He called me his doll-child, and he played with me just as I used

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: to play with my dolls. And when I came to live with you—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What sort of an expression is that to use about our marriage?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[undisturbed]_. I mean that I was simply transferred from papa’s hands

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: into yours. You arranged everything according to your own taste, and so

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I got the same tastes as you—or else I pretended to, I am really not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: quite sure which—I think sometimes the one and sometimes the other.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: When I look back on it, it seems to me as if I had been living here

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: like a poor woman—just from hand to mouth. I have existed merely to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: perform tricks for you, Torvald. But you would have it so. You and papa

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: have committed a great sin against me. It is your fault that I have

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: made nothing of my life.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: How unreasonable and how ungrateful you are, Nora! Have you not been

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: happy here?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I have never been happy. I thought I was, but it has never really

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: been so.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Not—not happy!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, only merry. And you have always been so kind to me. But our home

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: has been nothing but a playroom. I have been your doll-wife, just as at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: home I was papa’s doll-child; and here the children have been my dolls.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I thought it great fun when you played with me, just as they thought it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: great fun when I played with them. That is what our marriage has been,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: There is some truth in what you say—exaggerated and strained as your

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: view of it is. But for the future it shall be different. Playtime shall

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: be over, and lesson-time shall begin.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Whose lessons? Mine, or the children’s?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Both yours and the children’s, my darling Nora.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Alas, Torvald, you are not the man to educate me into being a proper

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: wife for you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And you can say that!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: And I—how am I fitted to bring up the children?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Didn’t you say so yourself a little while ago—that you dare not trust

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me to bring them up?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: In a moment of anger! Why do you pay any heed to that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Indeed, you were perfectly right. I am not fit for the task. There is

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: another task I must undertake first. I must try and educate myself—you

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: are not the man to help me in that. I must do that for myself. And that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: is why I am going to leave you now.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[springing up]_. What do you say?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I must stand quite alone, if I am to understand myself and everything

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: about me. It is for that reason that I cannot remain with you any

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: longer.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, Nora!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am going away from here now, at once. I am sure Christine will take

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me in for the night—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You are out of your mind! I won’t allow it! I forbid you!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is no use forbidding me anything any longer. I will take with me

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: what belongs to myself. I will take nothing from you, either now or

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: later.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What sort of madness is this!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Tomorrow I shall go home—I mean, to my old home. It will be easiest for

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me to find something to do there.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You blind, foolish woman!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I must try and get some sense, Torvald.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: To desert your home, your husband and your children! And you don’t

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: consider what people will say!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I cannot consider that at all. I only know that it is necessary for me.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: It’s shocking. This is how you would neglect your most sacred duties.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What do you consider my most sacred duties?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Do I need to tell you that? Are they not your duties to your husband

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and your children?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I have other duties just as sacred.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That you have not. What duties could those be?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Duties to myself.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Before all else, you are a wife and a mother.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I don’t believe that any longer. I believe that before all else I am a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: reasonable human being, just as you are—or, at all events, that I must

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: try and become one. I know quite well, Torvald, that most people would

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: think you right, and that views of that kind are to be found in books;

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: but I can no longer content myself with what most people say, or with

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: what is found in books. I must think over things for myself and get to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: understand them.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Can you not understand your place in your own home? Have you not a

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: reliable guide in such matters as that?—have you no religion?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I am afraid, Torvald, I do not exactly know what religion is.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: What are you saying?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I know nothing but what the clergyman said, when I went to be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: confirmed. He told us that religion was this, and that, and the other.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: When I am away from all this, and am alone, I will look into that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: matter too. I will see if what the clergyman said is true, or at all

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: events if it is true for me.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: This is unheard of in a girl of your age! But if religion cannot lead

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: you aright, let me try and awaken your conscience. I suppose you have

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: some moral sense? Or—answer me—am I to think you have none?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I assure you, Torvald, that is not an easy question to answer. I really

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: don’t know. The thing perplexes me altogether. I only know that you and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I look at it in quite a different light. I am learning, too, that the

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: law is quite another thing from what I supposed; but I find it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: impossible to convince myself that the law is right. According to it a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: woman has no right to spare her old dying father, or to save her

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: husband’s life. I can’t believe that.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You talk like a child. You don’t understand the conditions of the world

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: in which you live.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, I don’t. But now I am going to try. I am going to see if I can make

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: out who is right, the world or I.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You are ill, Nora; you are delirious; I almost think you are out of

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: your mind.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I have never felt my mind so clear and certain as tonight.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And is it with a clear and certain mind that you forsake your husband

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: and your children?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, it is.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Then there is only one possible explanation.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: What is that?

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: You do not love me anymore.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: No, that is just it.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora!—and you can say that?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It gives me great pain, Torvald, for you have always been so kind to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me, but I cannot help it. I do not love you any more.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[regaining his composure]_. Is that a clear and certain conviction

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: too?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, absolutely clear and certain. That is the reason why I will not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: stay here any longer.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: And can you tell me what I have done to forfeit your love?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Yes, indeed I can. It was tonight, when the wonderful thing did not

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: happen; then I saw you were not the man I had thought you were.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Explain yourself better. I don’t understand you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: I have waited so patiently for eight years; for, goodness knows, I knew

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: very well that wonderful things don’t happen every day. Then this

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: horrible misfortune came upon me; and then I felt quite certain that

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: the wonderful thing was going to happen at last. When Krogstad’s letter

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: was lying out there, never for a moment did I imagine that you would

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: consent to accept this man’s conditions. I was so absolutely certain

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: that you would say to him: Publish the thing to the whole world. And

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: when that was done—

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Yes, what then?—when I had exposed my wife to shame and disgrace?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: When that was done, I was so absolutely certain, you would come forward

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: and take everything upon yourself, and say: I am the guilty one.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora—!

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: You mean that I would never have accepted such a sacrifice on your

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: part? No, of course not. But what would my assurances have been worth

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: against yours? That was the wonderful thing which I hoped for and

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: feared; and it was to prevent that, that I wanted to kill myself.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I would gladly work night and day for you, Nora—bear sorrow and want

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: for your sake. But no man would sacrifice his honour for the one he

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: loves.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: It is a thing hundreds of thousands of women have done.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Oh, you think and talk like a heedless child.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Maybe. But you neither think nor talk like the man I could bind myself

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: to. As soon as your fear was over—and it was not fear for what

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: threatened me, but for what might happen to you—when the whole thing

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: was past, as far as you were concerned it was exactly as if nothing at

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: all had happened. Exactly as before, I was your little skylark, your

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: doll, which you would in future treat with doubly gentle care, because

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: it was so brittle and fragile. _[Getting up.]_ Torvald—it was then it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: dawned upon me that for eight years I had been living here with a

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: strange man, and had borne him three children—. Oh, I can’t bear to

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: think of it! I could tear myself into little bits!

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: _[sadly]_. I see, I see. An abyss has opened between us—there is no

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: denying it. But, Nora, would it not be possible to fill it up?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: As I am now, I am no wife for you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: I have it in me to become a different man.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Perhaps—if your doll is taken away from you.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But to part!—to part from you! No, no, Nora, I can’t understand that

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: idea.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[going out to the right]_. That makes it all the more certain that it

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: must be done. _[She comes back with her cloak and hat and a small bag

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: which she puts on a chair by the table.]_

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Nora, Nora, not now! Wait until tomorrow.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting on her cloak]_. I cannot spend the night in a strange man’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: room.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But can’t we live here like brother and sister—?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[putting on her hat]_. You know very well that would not last long.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: _[Puts the shawl round her.]_ Goodbye, Torvald. I won’t see the little

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: ones. I know they are in better hands than mine. As I am now, I can be

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: of no use to them.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But some day, Nora—some day?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: How can I tell? I have no idea what is going to become of me.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: But you are my wife, whatever becomes of you.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: Listen, Torvald. I have heard that when a wife deserts her husband’s

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: house, as I am doing now, he is legally freed from all obligations

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: towards her. In any case, I set you free from all your obligations. You

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: are not to feel yourself bound in the slightest way, any more than I

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: shall. There must be perfect freedom on both sides. See, here is your

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: ring back. Give me mine.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: That too?

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That too.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: Here it is.

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: That’s right. Now it is all over. I have put the keys here. The maids

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: know all about everything in the house—better than I do. Tomorrow,

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: after I have left her, Christine will come here and pack up my own

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: things that I brought with me from home. I will have them sent after

SPEAKER: NORA
TEXT: me.

SPEAKER: HELMER
TEXT: All over! All over!—Nora, shall you never think of me again?
